content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Don't lie. You're reading these reviews to build your hype for Fallout 4 for some reason. It's okay, I am too.EDIT 11/10/2015: You know what day it is right? Like, why are you reading this?P.S. Because I'm getting messages and comments from people saying "Can I play this on Win 7???" I'm just gonna list out the fixes required to make sure it runs just like it would on Vista (but better because you know, you're running 7 for a reason).1. Crash/Freezing issue at random points in the game:     -Run the game at least once    -Go here ( C:\Users\[Username]\Documents\My Games\Fallout3\Fallout.ini )    -Press "Ctrl+F" type (without quotation marks) "bUseThreadedAI"    -Should read "bUseThreadedAI=0", change the 0 to 1 (if this line isn't there, add it anywhere in the      block of lines above the [Display] category of the file)    -(This next line shouldn't be in your file already but do a quick Ctrl+F to make sure, if it is change      it accordingly)    -Directly underneath "bUseThreadedAI=1", write "iNumHWThreads=2". If it's already there, just      change whatever value it is to "2".    Save & Exit2. Radio Music Stuttering     Preface: Now even with this fix in place, I still find occasional bouts where either music will not                  play from my Pip-Boy or the stuttering will return in a certain area for some odd reason.                  This is just a general fix that will help alleviate stuttering for ~95% of your game time.    -Download MADFilter      ( http://sourceforge.net/projects/maddxshow/files/MAD%20Filter/MADFilter%201.0.0.3/ )    -Extract "MADFilter.ax", "register.bat" and "unregister.bat" file to ( C:\Windows\SysWOW64 for      64-bit OS's or C:\Windows\system for 32-bit OS's)    -Once you've extracted the files to your directory, run the register.bat that is currently in your      SysWOW64 or system folder.    -Just to make sure you did the work correctly, download "InstalledCodec"      ( http://www.nirsoft.net/utils/installedcodec.zip ), extract the zip and run the .exe once extracted    -Look for "MAD Transform Filter" and make sure it's installed. THEN, find "Fraunhofer IIS MPEG      Layer-3 Codec" in the utility. Right click it and select "Disable Selected Items"    Run the game and on your pip-boy radio, select Galaxy News radio and listen to see if the     stuttering is still there. If it is, then you should go back and check which directory you pasted     the MADFilter file into and check InstalledCodec to ensure the MAD filter is installed and enabled     and then make sure the Fraunhofer codec is DISABLED. If this didn't work, there is a conflict     within your codecs and you may have another MP3 Codec installed and working on top of your     MAD Filter. I'd check InstalledCodec and see what may be conflicting.    Credit to GoldenShadow for helping me fix this years ago     ( http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=844931 )3. Random Crashes and Freezing fix AFTER the Fallout.ini fix:    This little guy over at Nexus may have a fix for you. If you're still crashing and freezing and have     no clue why, try downloading his d3d9.dll file and insert it into your game's source directory.    Download link: ( http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/18900/? )    (If you're in the same boat as myself and still have random crashes, freezes and all sorts of odd     mishaps in your game and you've done all of the fixes listed above, I'm afraid I have no other help     considering I've dug pretty far to find some other fixes and nothing has really helped. Best to just     Quicksave (F5 by default) as often as possible)P.P.S. Edited for Win 8 & 8.1 compatibility fixes (The following is provided thanks to the very generous blue_light1554)1. Basically, if your computer has two cores, you have to follow French Girls' steps for only "1. Crash/Freezing issue at random points in the game:"2. Save the modified notepad text and exit.3. Then you put compatibility mode: Windows XP Service Pack 3You do that for "Fallout 3 Launcher" and the application named "Fallout 3".(...\Steam\Steamapps\Common\Fallout 3)4. Then visit this website: http://www.xbox.com/en-US/live/pc/DownloadClientThis will make you download a missing client required to make Fallout 3 work.5. When you've done all that, you right click on the Fallout 3 application and do "Run as Administrator"6. It should work!7. I'm not an expert so if you have questions or it didn't work for you, go see the website shown here:  http://help.bethsoft.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/9977 Maybe you'll find something else useful.EDIT 11/6/2013: I just upgrade from Win 7 to Win 10 and I can confirm Fallout 3 runs fine on the same exact system I did an entire playthrough on. Loaded it up and ran around a bit and it played just like it did on 7.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Fallout 3 isn't just a game, It's an experience.Wow, since I'am getting so many thumbs up, I feel I should write something useful about this game and why I personally recommend it.+ One big continuous open world. Loading screens appear only when entering major cities or buildings.+ Very atmospheric and immersive world to explore.+ Every NPC’s are really living in that world. They follow their own daily routine from morning to night. You’ll meet them, talk to them and even remember their names.+ Good writing and a touching story. It is fun to talk to NPC’s and trying out different dialogue options to see the outcome.+ Freedom in almost every aspect. A quest can be completed in many ways. You can almost kill anybody you meet (even an entire town). You can be a good guy, a bad guy or have a mix of both. You can play as an action game or you can play stealthily. You can choose to play in 1st person or 3rd person. You can roam anywhere you want but….+ Enemies don’t scale.  So if you wander off to the wrong area during early levels, you will die easily.+ Many types of interesting enemies. Some are scary.+ Graphics.+ Voice acting.+ VATS+ Mods. A lot of them.+ Galaxy News Radio and...+ Three Dogs.+- Progression system and level cap (max level 30). The progression system is fun and addictive (with a lot of useful perks to choose) but I personally prefer Elder Scroll’s progression system where you get better at what you use. This way you can shape your preferred character with more flexibility and can even change your play style anytime. That’s why it is not a negative, it’s something that I have a mixed feeling.+- Dynamic day & night cycle. This game has day and night cycle but it is purely for cosmetic effect and doesn’t change or affect gameplay.- A.I’s are stupid sometimes, especially if you play stealthily.- Stealth gameplay could be better. Most area design doesn’t encourage stealth gameplay. No non-lethal option either.- Crafting options are very few. (Mods fixes this) - No iron sight aiming in 1st person. (Mods fixes this)

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Immersive & stimulating // Recommended for marathon gamers looking to get lost in a worldThis review is based on a purely vanilla playthrough.+ RPG & levelling elements; fairly standard in practice, but work well and mesh perfectly with the feel of the game+ Myriad available perks add enormous flexibility to a player's role+ Karma system is a lot of fun to play around with, and also goes a long way to showcase the consequences of one's actions+ Combat is fairly run-of-the-mill for an RPG FPS; certainly not fast-paced, but is implemented in a way that rewards planning and preparedeness+ V.A.T. system functions well-beyond a simple gimmick; functional to the point of being vital in its proper use, intensely fun, and sensationally cinematic (save for one minor scruple, outlined below)+ Environment, while graphically aged, is nonetheless incredibly detailed; there are always interesting things to find off the beaten path, and the player is encouraged in (and often rewarded for) exploring+ Map is expansive and populated with secrets and locations to visit+ Voice-acting is largely excellent, with only a few minor characters standing out as being less than exemplary in vocal quality+ Side-missions are well-detailed, fun & interesting to complete; the rewards for doing so can sometimes be extraordinary+ Plot moves forward at a pace set by the player, and is interesting to see through to the conclusion; writing ranges from passable to excellent, and never strays from the game's established charm+ Total freedom in the way problems are solved and obstables overcome+ Extremely, stupidly mod-friendly (via third-party applications - I recommend NexusMod, personally)+ Modular damage, for both the player and encountered enemies, is very well-implemented; damage to certain areas of the body will hurt perfomance appropriately, further emphasizing a sense of immersion+ Boasts a seemingly unending variety of items and weaponry; the hoarding game is real- Oddly enough, this game uses GFWL, but is easily bypassed (simply by exiting out); this won't be counted thrice against the game (as GFWL, in this case, appears bafflingly neutered), but it does pop up, so it should be mentioned- Camera can sometimes prove buggy and unreliable during V.A.T. kills- Character models and animations are below-average in presentation (easily remedied via third-party mods, of course)- There seems to be a bug where GFWL asks for a nonexistent product key; this is easily bypassed by simply exiding GFWL within the running gameLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												The first "Fallout" game that I ever played. Got it on sale on Steam about a year after it came out (09').  I had no friends that had this game and I knew little to nothing about the story/gameplay etc. other then what Steam listed.  I love RPG games w/FPS elements, Deus Ex being another. Fallout 3 does a great job of letting you go at your own pace and shows what an open world environment can really feel like.  How the game starts  is fun too, seeing parts of your childhood. As the time comes when you leave your vault for first time the games says "You have a main mission to do but what's that place over there...".  It was impossible to see every thing even the first few time you play thru the game and I was always finding new places, people, missions, and weapons.  On top of all that there are 5 DLCs that add more areas to visit ("The Pitt" and "Broken Steel" being my Fav) and help fill out the game even better then most other games I've played.  Most of my playthroughs still take as much as 100+ hours if you take time to visit most/all places as well as do all missions possible for you.  One last thing is this game has a fantastic modding community that can spice up the game and fix/improve just about any area you could think of in this game from, graphics/terrain to weapons/NPCs.  A must have game for RPG/FPS lovers.***9/10***

												This game is not just The elder scrolls with guns. Fallout 3 is a very easy game to immerse yourself into. I even find it difficult to be an evil character because of all the hard choices you can make in this game. Decisions can effect this game greatly for example there is a choice to blow up a town with a nuke. Karma is truly a b*tch in this game. It also does a good job at giving you that 1950's vibe. And especially the post-apocalyptic survivalist feeling. The exploration in the game is amazing with so many places to explore I have played this game for over 4 years and I dont think I have even covered the entire Capital Wasteland. The graphics could be better and there are a few bugs here and there but overall this game is completely worth buying you will not be disappointed. And remember "War. War Never Changes."

												This is going to be a long reivew for Fallout 3 (YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED)Set-Up: 


ULTIMATE Fallout 3 Setup & Mod guide Windows 10, 8 & 7 
A Guide for Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
By: BenWah

			The best setup guide for Fallout 3!		


(Follow this guide in order to successfully play Fallout 3 on your Windows 7 & above)After getting this game to work properly on my windows 8, it still stands out to be the 'better' (in my opinion) fallout game for this generation of gamers. No disrespect to Fallout: New Vegas but i feel that game focuses mainly on survival and a 'western' setting rather than a true 'post-apocalyptic' like you see in Fallout 3.Mods make this game so much better, but however much more dangerous and unstable so install mods wisely. My advice? install small things like the street light mod and also install FOSE in order to get those working of couse and after maybe a couple of days of playing Fallout 3 with one simple mod gradually expand outward to big & better mods. Be careful though most mods require the DLC so get the DLC to the game ASAP (Which isn't a bad thing of course gives your system more 'breathing' room, but that's just my point of view).If you want a true wasteland expereince install the F03 Wanderers Edition from the Nexus to get the LOL! 'hardcore' mode that F:NV had but Fallout 3 didn't there is a ton of exploration to do in Fallout 3 (quicksave often) from the wasteland itself to the underbelly of the creepy, and dark subway systems. There is so much to do and so little time to do it.The companions in this game aren't really all that great they charge into a heated battle with a 99% chance of dying depending upon who you are fighting (ironically i perfer F:NV compainon system as they are 'smarter' than the ones in Fallout 3)By the end of the day Fallout 3 still stands as my personal  'post-apocalyptic' game to date, So if you want to explore the  harsh wasteland armed with an assault rifle and a whiskey bottle then this game is for you!

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												When Fallout 3 was announced in 2004, not everyone was happy to hear that Bethesda would be the development studio to bring the Wasteland to life. The franchise's most hardcore fans were up in arms when they found out that their beloved Fallout was being turned into a first-person role-playing game, abandoning the originals' isometric perspective and "dumbing it down" for consoles. Plenty of folks complained that the game would just end up being "Oblivion with guns" (of course, some would argue that that's not exactly a bad thing, as 2006's Elder Scrolls title was one of that year's finest RPGs). I can safely say that while Fallout 3 bears an uncanny resemblance to Oblivion in some ways, but it's also a far superior game in many others.In the year 2077, nuclear war ravaged the world and forced a segment of the human race (well, the lucky ones anyway) underground to live out their days in massive Vaults that could protect them from the radiation-spawned terrors lurking outside in the Wasteland. Although the first two games in the Fallout series took place on the West Coast, Fallout 3 is set in the greater Washington D.C. area. Naturally, this means you'll see plenty of familiar landmarks, from the Washington Monument to the White House. You may be saddened to see that the famed Tidal Basin cherry blossoms don't bloom during a nuclear winter.Some 200 years after this nuclear holocaust, your character is born inside of one of these subterranean sanctuaries. The game actually kicks off after a brief prologue, with your character being forced out of the safety of your mother's womb into the hands of your waiting father. You'll take this time to name yourself and complete a "projection" of what you'll look like when you grow to adulthood, at which point your father's face will finally come into view. It's an interesting way to handle character creation, as well as show off the game's unique approach to presentation and customization.Before leaving the safety of the Vault for the horrors of the world outside, you'll need to determine what sort of character you'll be and how you'll approach the game. This begins when you find a book called "You're S.P.E.C.I.A.L.," which teaches you about the most basic level of character creation. This is where you'll set your core attributes that will determine your Strength, Perception, Endurance, and so on. These attributes remain largely the same as you progress through the game, although you'll have the rare chance to alter them with perks, equipment, or good old-fashioned drugs. Once you've set your core attributes, you'll need to take a test to determine which skills your character is most adept at using. Like Oblivion, you'll have just over a dozen skills that you can excel in, with three of those being marked as tag skills. After taking the Generalized Occupational Aptitude Test (G.O.A.T.), you'll learn which skills you're best-suited to using, although it should be noted that you can choose your own destiny and fight against the establishment that's telling you how to live your life by choosing the skills you want to focus on. The test is actually more of a psychological profile than an actual test, with your answers determining where your strengths lie. While Fallout 3 could technically be called a first-person shooter, those looking for a Call of Duty 4-style experience will likely be disappointed. It's possible to run 'n gun your way through the game, but the FPS controls just aren't quite up to snuff. Thankfully this is alright since you've got the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System (VATS) to help you in combat. Utilizing VATS stops the action and allows you to target individual body parts, which are presented with the percentage chance that you have of successfully hitting them. You'll likely spend the majority of your time in combat using VATS, occasionally finishing off your foes in real-time when you run out of the action points that fuels VATS.One area in which Fallout 3 doesn't resemble Oblivion is in its leveling system. While Oblivion rewarded you for doing specific things throughout the course of the game, here you'll only be able to upgrade your skills by earning experience points. These can be gained by doing everything from killing enemies and completing quests to winning speech challenges and successfully hacking computer terminals. There were times when I missed the ability to focus on improving a particular skill, although not having to spend hours practicing our sneaking skills just to gain a level or two was actually quite liberating.While there are plenty of memorable characters and places throughout the game, the real star of the show is the massive, wide-open environment. It's incredibly easy to get distracted from the main quest, and that's part of the fun, as you'll find yourself getting sucked into one side quest after another as your explore the Wasteland. Of course, this can lead to moments when you'll need to spend an inordinate amount of time walking from one location to the next, as you can't use the game's fast-travel system if you haven't visited your target location at least once. There are times when it feels like a bit of a grind, though at least you'll stumble upon plenty of cool locations during your travels. Given that it uses the same Gamebryo engine that powered Oblivion, it's probably not surprising to learn that Fallout 3 is a helluva great-looking game. Sure, the characters still look a bit weird while they're talking, and you'll likely notice some draw distance issues no matter which version you play, but this is still one of the most visually impressive games of 2008. The PC version looks particularly nice, especially since it runs at a smooth and steady 60 frames per second with only occasional dips. Fallout 3 is an admirable achievement for Bethesda. It’s a game that provides action, adventure, exploration, interaction and excitement in a beautifully realised Armageddon that provides so many unexpected moments, but somehow manages to remain consistent and believable.

												Amazing game, I originally played this on the PS3 when it first came out. Was pretty good but graphics sucked because I was broke at the time and playing it on a 19 inch CRT (like the ones you used to have in your bedroom in the 90's). So when I bought this on a steam sale for like $5 or something. I decided I would play it right. I then spent the next 2 days, modding the heck out of it with Nexus Mod's. Oh my I made this 6 year old game look fricking goergous. Much prettier then even Skyrim. It was one of the most immersive game's I had ever played. (One of the mods I used launched it in a weird way so steam never recorded my time playing it which is why it says iv only played it for 5 minutes). I seriously recomend picking this up in a steam sale, and take your time modding it. Then get a good solid uninterupted weekend, Lots of nice cold water and some snacks. And just sit there and play the crap out of it for that awsome weekend. It's that type of game.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												I am going to start this review with controversy. Of the Fallout series I think Fallout 3 is the best of them. Now before you start flaming me over the fact your prefer Fallout: New Vegas or Fallout 1 for instance, let me try and explain this.Fallout 1 & 2 remain good classics, that must be played by any fan of the later Fallouts, if only for the feel of it for the moment. The first Fallouts had the best incentive to go away from the safety of community, because either your vault or your tribe was in danger - both of them showing much of Fallout world. However, that said although I enjoy pixelated games... they are pixalated games and some of the tactic options are for the time excellent, but now outdated.Fallout 3's incentive to travel is a bit odd. You must basically because you are thrown out and you are supposed to set out on your family member that walked out on you (before you go 'What?!', sorry I won't spoil more). This incentive is rather... odd. However, than comes Fallout 3 itself. Although opinions aside about the radio jockey - a controversy in the community - the added old school music and now stunning graphics make the Fallout world come to live. Although some errors in cannon can be found, most quests are excellent and tie into the world itself. Also allowing free roaming like the old game, but now the road itself is just as interresting - something Fallout 1 & 2 were less able do due to technical reasons (random encounters based on luck (or unluck)).The main quest can be ended in much shorter time than I played in it, heck I have several lives, but I also have but one expansion. Still if you focus on only the mainquest than you are doing it wrong. Go out and explore and feel like an adventurer in a dismal post-apocolyptic world.

content:
Posted: January 16
												A DAY IN THE WORLD OF FALLOUT 3As you open the door out of Moriarty’s Saloon into the broken-down city of Megaton, the sun blinds you, reminding the inhabitants of the Wasteland of the power of radiation. You walk down the rickety old stairs and into the heart of the town. People greet you as you pass, and you can almost smell their respect for you, as you have shown your resolve many times by defending their lives. Your laser rifle bounces on your Vault-Tec armored jumpsuit, and your trusty 32. Caliber pistol hangs at your side. As you are about to leave the rundown town, a tall man in a hat and sheriff’s badge approaches you. He tells you of a group of Super-Mutants that has attacked a nearby village. He offers 700 caps for you to eradicate them, a handsome reward. You pull out your Pip-Boy on your arm, and mark the destination on your map. You nod your thanks to the sheriff, and set out, your loyal dog at your side. The doors out of the city open, and the strong smell of death and smoke fills your nostrils. You resist the urge to guzzle your bottle of whisky in your pack, knowing that you will need the ability to perceive all you can in the battle ahead.               As you reach the war-torn village, you hear the cries of the Mutants and the screams of the people, as they flee in terror. A Super Mutant notices you, and grabbing his club, he runs at you, yelling murderous threats. You calmly take out your rifle, aim, and blow his head off his shoulders. You feel the acidic blood spray your skin as the giant topples to the ground in a heap. You walk over to the corpse and feel his pockets for stray caps. None. You grunt, drawing your pistol and shooting the arm off an incoming Super-Mutant. He falls to his knees, yelling guttural cries at you. You walk over to him and, brandishing your brass knuckles, punch him in the face so hard that you feel his bones break. As his limp body crumples to the ground, you see who you came here for. Over twelve feet tall, brandishing an assault rifle and nail-board, clad in Kevlar armor was the chieftain, the Super-Mutant Brute. He roars, firing round after round at you, as you try to find cover. As the bullets pierce the bunker that you hide behind, you ready a bottlecap mine. As you hear the gun click and the cursing stop, you know that the creature is reloading his weapon. You quickly stand up, and diving for cover, throw the highly explosive mine at his feet. Too preoccupied with filling his gun with more rounds, he doesn’t seem to notice it. You aim your pistol at his feet, thinking to blow the mine where he stands. The Brute lets out a raucous laugh, reaches down, and picking up the bottlecap mine, he hurls it at you. Your vision blurs in a burst of light, and searing pain covers your entire body. Your eyes burn and you can only see a hazy sight of a hulking creature walk over to you. It raises a large object, and brings it down on your head in a flash of bright light, then, everything goes dark.Fallout 3 is a gritty, atmospheric, open-world RPG that has you exploring a post-apocalyptic wasteland crawling with both friendly and combative inhabitants. With a cast of interesting and unforgettable characters, along with the most unique locations to explore, and a deep and brutal combat system to bind it all together, the world of Fallout is a masterpiece. With its immersive sound and visual design, you will soon start to feel the effects of radiation on your body as you enter the world Fallout 3. Welcome to the Wasteland.

number of helpful: 30 of 33 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												This game is easily one of my favorite games of all time, just everything about it I love. Bethesda really nails the whole post-apocalyptic feeling, because everything just feels empty and deserted. These days the game looks pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and even back in 2008 when I first played this game, I didn't think it looked that impressive (Dem Mods though). I admit that I'm a little spoiled by New Vegas, so the mechanics in FO3 don't feel quite as good as they do in New Vegas, but using VATS and the gameplay itself is excellent. I enjoyed all the songs in the game, but I really wish they would have added more, especially with all the DLC this game has. The karma system is something I feel all RPG's should have and while some of the decisions you make don't really affect things as a whole, it's still nice to have multiple choices to the quests you do. Audio as a whole is excellent (as stated with the music) but it just feels limited with the amount of the voice actors and the songs on the radio, the quality is definitely there though. I honestly could keep going on why I love this game so much and there is a lot of stuff I haven't even seen yet (DLC and Mods) but there is one big issue that makes me question this version in particular. On Windows 7, this game would crash at least every hour for me and sometimes it would be even worse. You would think with a game as popular as FO3, that Bethesda would at least fix something as big as this is, but they haven't. I have played this on Xbox 360 before and it maybe crashed 1 or 2 times (it's pretty sad when the console version of your game, performs better than the far superior PC). If you can deal with the technical issues, then you're in for one of the best RPG's of all time, up there with games like Mass Effect 2, Dragon Age: Origins, Skyrim, and KOTOR. Regardless of any of the negative things I said about FO3, I think one of the most important aspects of any game is fun and if I can sit and enjoy a game for extended play sessions for weeks and keep coming back to it after I already beat it before, well I think that's what every game should strive for.10/10 A Masterpiece

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												A wonderful game - given 9/10 almost perfect. I found this game to very enjoyable. Unlike many of our games today. This one felt much more immersive. Despite having older graphics and sometimes glitchy gameplay. The story and moral choices are touching and make you almost geninually care about finding your dad. Gameplay wise it is very well rounded. Unlike Fallout NV combat is much more simple. Seeing as how there is simply one type of ammo. Then you shoot said ammo. Nothing else. But NV boasted more guns and more mods for guns. But if you want a much better made game Fallout 3 is probably a better choice. It really works well on immersion. It lacks the painful abundance of loading screens in NV. While the wasteland around you almost feels fearful. Seeing as how you can run into raiders/mutants/dogs/bears/and basiclly anything else. If you are looking for a memorable game. This is probably it. HOWEVER one problem I noticed was that there was a point that one will reach in the game. Where finding supplies become basiclly an after thought. Seeing as how I soon had stocked up 400+ "rare" MC cells. This impairs it but not totally killing it. If you had to buy either NV or 3. Choose 3 <----------- half loaf 3 confirmed

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												(Don't focus too much on the negative reviews because it's mainly about a number of people that don't know how to search up a simple tutorial or a guide on how to fix the optimization issue) The main reason why I started to play Fallout 3 is because of hype for Fallout 4. I'm waiting for so long and it's getting on my nerves quite frankly. But, at some time when I was playing, this idea got off of my mind and I actually had one of the most fun that I ever had during my playtime. The gameplay feels right, the pip-boy is a great feature, the soundtrack and the music has to be one of the best to date, and the story is amazing. If you like RPGs and open-world games, this is totally a must buy. But the debate comes upon everyone every once in a while about, which Fallout game is better. Fallout New Vegas or Fallout 3? Well, I couldn't decide so I just bought both of them. But if you want to look at the open world aspect and the terrain, Fallout 3 is a lot better. The empty wasteland of Fallout New Vegas just seemed a little boring, only seeing something interesting in your path every now and again. It might be a little trouble first playing it because of the compatibilitie issues, but once you've fixed that, you'll have fun. PS: What are you doing reading my review?! Go play Fallout 4 right now!

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
FALLOUT 3 GAME REVIEWIntroductionWhen I was younger, I played this game on XBOX (those were dark days) and failed to even reach megaton (The first place you come to in the open world after what is essentially a tutorial level). Got fallout new vegas on steam soon after I got a gaming PC. I loved it. I loved skyrim too so i decided to replay fallout 3 to see if i was just an idiot when i was younger. SPOILER. i was.It has a few issues with windows 7, and multiple monitors but more or less all bug fixes can be found here[pcgamingwiki.com]. nexus mod manager has loads of bug fixes and graphical upgrades for those who wan't them. If you are just interested in how good I thing this game is, and not why it is, then skip to the conclusion. but i urge you to read the whole thing to make up your own mindNegativesHere are a few things that are wrong with this game.1.No Patch or bug fix for windows 7this game has been about for ages. but it refuses to work with modern operating systems. bethesda could get so many more sales if they just released a patch. they could just release some user created patch's as an update. it wouldn't even take much time or money. This is (in my opinion) their best game and its going into a state of ruin. if the modding community was not there to support it. it wouldn't even be playable.2.Games for windows liveOk so it's not as bad as uplay or god forbid, origin, but its still irritating. not to mention the fact that it has cause numorous bugs and save corruptions/wipes in many games. many games now are having this tumor surgically removed but not this one. you can patch it out using mods and nexus mod manager but this should have been done as a patch by bethesda. Again, bethesda's best game is being dragged down by the lack of a simple patch, that not only would increase the sales and plays of the game but be cheap and cost virtually no time at all. 3.When  Your father dies  so your dad has this big project that is called project purity and it basically produces purified water from dirty water. and these bad guys called the enclave want it so they can infect it with a virus and wipe out all humans and other species who have even slightly mutated  since the war 200 years ago. and at the controll panel they ask your dad to activate it so he locks the door and floods it with radiation. one question. WHY???. at this point in the game i had full power armor (T51-B arguably the best model in the game) and ton of alien weaponry (from motehrship zeta). and he only killed some general guy and a foot soldier. i killed more men just getting here! his death was unneccisary and it really feels like its shoe-horned in to give the player a reason to hate the enclave.4.The endingThe ending is complete rubbish. you have a choice to sacrifice yourself or tell either your mutant side-kick (if you have him) who won't actually die or some random brotherhood of steel woman to sacrifice themselves instead. i have a number of problems with this, the first being that if you chose to let them die, you die anyway, with no explination. the game simpley fades away and starts narating your life and all the stuff you have done. no explination given at all. its like they just ran out of time and said "well people will only choose to sacrifice themselves right? ... right? ... RIGHT?". not to mention the fact taht you only die because you need to enter the room your dad filled with radiation for no good reason!  THIS MAKES THE BROKEN STEEL DLC  PRETTY MUCH REQUIRED - thats all im saying without using spoilers  becasue it increases level cap and removes the crappy ending. as well as giving a flimsy explination as to why you 'died' even if you didn't sacrifice yourself.PositivesBut that's just the negatives, here are some positives:1.It is bethesda's best gameif you like skyrim. its that but with technology instead of magic and guns. lots and lots of guns.2.It is scary.not the jump scare kind of way. this game is atmospherically scary. when you are trekking through the abandoned, dark gloomy subway tunnels hearing the muffeled movement of the ghoulified remains of humans all around you. it getts pretty tense. afetr a while of straight playing you become slightly desensitised to the fear. but it's really good while it lasts and if you get the point lookout DLC then it does (when you travel to point lookout anyway) become really scarry again. 3.The story is amazingThe story, despite its faults, is really good. it becomes really immersive and the choices you have to make are sometimes really moraly grey. for instance i had a choice between killing this man who was routed to the spot for decades, unable to move, with little conversation and immense boredom. while having his insides torn slowly from his body by a tree that had grown around him. or speeding up the recovery of the wasteland. and improving life for everyone. it was a really difficult choice but I had to choose improving everyones life over his.4.World Designthe world is teeming with secrets and, while it may not be very large, requires quite a lot of exploration to find everything. random encounters make thsi all the more intresting also.ConclusionIn conclusion, I think Fallout 3 is an excellent game. it may have its issues, but most can be fixed by getting the DLC and user created mod's.It is by far bethesda's greatest game and the best in the fallout franchise. it is lore is rich and immersive and the music is some of the best i have heard (in terms of actually songs that include vocals and are in the game as radio tracks or jukebox records. not background music). The lack of achievements is saddening. I would really like to 100% this game, but alass it seems bethesda did little more than shove this game on steam without continuued support or additional features. a shame really.If I was to give an arbitrary score to this game it would be around 8/10, losing a point purely for its lack of achievements, a few story plot holes and its inability to work on most windows 7 (and 8) PC's. overall its a great game and i completely recromend it over fallout: new vegas. or any game for that matter. just make sure you get the broken steel DLC and point lookout if you want to keep the scary atmosphere going.

number of helpful: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												I thought i should rewrite my review, since my old one is.. well old, and horrible, so here we go! This game is probably the most unique game i've ever played, its a open world RPG much like The Elder Scrolls games, but Fallout has much more, such as radiation poisining, cripable limbs, better atmosphere and more realisim. The story begins with your birth, and in a quick pace progresses to the most important moments of your childhood, such as the time you get your Pipboy 3000. You live in Vault 101, a place made to keep its citizens alive during the nuclear war that happened on the surface. But, Vault 101's doors never opened after the nuclear war. Everybody was to repopulate and die in Vault 101, nobody was to leave and nobody was to enter. But of course you got out because.. who would want to live in a scary vault filled with people for the rest of your life? After your childhood "dream" ends you are awakened by alarms, you are very confused. Your best friend tells you that your father left Vault 101. You decide to leave Vault 101, as it is no longer safe, creatures from the outside have poured in because of your father opening the Vault door. When going outside of the vault, you can already feel the atmosphere, how amazing it is. In the distance you see cities, and of course, The wastelands. Now you should be ready to feel the awesomeness of the game, the quests. In Fallout 3, there are many ways to finish quests. Lets say you need to get past a door, but you need a key to open the door. You could always pick pocket the person who owns the key, but depending on your skill level, he will notice, and start to kill you. You could also blow his brains out, easiest way to do it. But whatever you do, it will impact the future of your game. If you were bad throughout the game, and killed lots of innocent people, your Karma will go down. But if you do good things, your Karma will stay at a neutral level, or gain. Everytime you level up, you can choose a perk you would like to advance in, and you will get a certain amount of skill points to upgrade your stats. Also, theres a neat aiming system called VATs, its really hard to explain what it actually does, but you could always YouTube it.Graphics: 8/10 (they are good, but not even close to newer games)Sound: 9/10Gameplay: 9.5/10

												The quests and atmosphere are where this game shines. It's staggering how nearly every character you meet has an interesting story to tell considering how large the game world is, and, especially for first time players, the ruins of D.C. provide a fun mix of rubble, raiders, and scenic views to keep you occupied as you traverse from one mysterious tick on your compass to another. Just like so many other Bethesda games, the main questline isn't very interersting compared to the other quests scattered throughout the world, and you'll find yourself putting it off until later over and over. Oh, and blowing the heads off raiders is super satisfying.

Posted: July 15, 2016
												Well if you havent heard of Fallout 3 yet, you've missed quite a lot.It's a fun, giant open world filled with lore, humor, items, weaponry, bandits, ammunation and death. I must admit, I enjoyed Fallout: New Vegas more than this game but that doesn't mean the Fallout 3 is not a great game. Hell, it's one hell of a good game! The gameplay is really fun, using VATS or just sniping the badguys, looting their bodies afterwards. If you want you can also take a loyal (but sometimes annoying) companion with you so your journey on this hell bent wasteland is not so bad and not so lonely. You can also switch between first and third-person if you like while in the background some smooth 20th century music is playing as you sneak towards and pickpocket your typical bandit, headshot that supermutant from 100m away or feed the ghouls some lead with the minigun you just found.Fallout 3 provides a lot of fun gameplay and a world you can delve into.

Posted: May 3, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients: 1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs3 tablespoons sugar3 tablespoons melted butter40 ounces softened cream cheese1 cup sugar3 tablespoons flour1 tablespoon vanilla1 cup sour cream4 eggsDirections:For The base:.If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.For the batter:.Make sure everything is at room temperature.Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.Release the sides of the springform.Eat.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
TLDR VERDICTThough dated, Fallout 3s good writing and survivalist atmosphere more than makes up for the technical and visual issues. A good 100+ hour world to get lost in, and would recommend DLCs too.FULL REVIEW BELOW“Man had succeeded in destroying the world – but war, war never changes” – Ron PearlmanThe year is 2277 and it has been 200 years since the Great War that consumed the Earth in nuclear fire and radiation. You are a resident of Vault 101, one of many underground shelters built before the war. The door to Vault 101 slides open for the first time in 200 years, and you emerge into the ruins of Washington D.C, now known as The Capital Wasteland.This review is written from the perspective of a fan of RPGs and story-driven games, who hasn’t played any other Fallout games.GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNFallout 3 is a massive open world sandbox RPG that can be played from a first or third-person perspective. You are thrust into the world and given a goal, but it is up to you to decide how long you want to take to reach it. The Capital Wasteland is a harsh and sprawling land that lets you go wherever you want, whenever you want. The map is absolutely huge, consisting of downtown DC and all of its surrounding areas ranging from sewers to suburbs. The absolutely huge amount of approaches to the land can be overwhelming for some players. You may struggle with knowing where to start, especially given the fact the game offers very little direction. Just doing quests would probably only uncover a quarter to a third of the entire map, so players that prefer independent exploration and spontaneous discovery will get a lot of more value vs. someone who follows the quest markers.The progression system is fair and you start to feel more powerful over the course of the game, however by the end if you play your stats right you can literally have a jack of all trades, master of all character. Being able to cap every single stat on one character can eliminate some replay ability meaning the only reason to start another character would be alternative morality choices. On the other hand, it does eliminate the annoying factor of not being able to see what’s behind that door because I’m one point too short in this specific stat for people who don’t have time for 5 different playthroughs. Enemy difficulty adapts to your character level rather than the areas. This means that no matter where you go, the enemies will always be at your level. This is good as it keeps the combat fresh and evolving all the way to the very end, but bad because you can't stomp early game areas. It also allows players to explore freely at any point in the game without the risk of being suddenly disintegrated by some level 30 mob and losing 3 hours of progress because you forgot to save. I really like the way the game handles the exploration and looting systems. You can fast travel back to any area you’ve discovered. This sparks the age old argument of immersion vs. quality of life, but hey, you’re not forced to use it. As you work your way through the game you slowly progress from picking up as much useless crap as you can carry to analysing the environment and cherry picking the most relevant and valuable stuff. For example, I didn’t see the point in lugging around a motorcycle gas tank until I found out you can build a flaming sword out of them and began hunting for them. I hoarded seemingly useless scrap metal until it paid off because it turned out some guy in a city was willing to pay for it to fix some pipes. I felt a wasteland junk expert by the end, as my approach to every new room became systematically rummaging through filing cabinets and desks for valuables that extend beyond money vs. not money.STORY AND NARRATIVEFallout 3s story is essentially structured into the main quest, side quests and DLC quests.  The main quest itself is a pretty mediocre story about finding your dad. It has its moments, but ultimately just serves to give the game a beginning and end. The middle portion, you will spend getting lost in the sometimes great, sometimes bad and sometimes plain weird side quests. The side quests are few in number (given the games size) and you won’t see 4 or 5 people with floating question marks on their heads asking you to fetch 12 bear asses. The role play aspect plays a big role in these side quests, allowing you to morally be the second coming of Christ, a boring stoic neutral dude, or Lucifer himself. This can cause quests to branch a few different ways (your stats can come into play during conversations too) but ultimately it usually ends up resulting to being good or evil. The excellent DLC packs definitely present a lot more ambiguous choices where you really have to think about things beyond being good or evil. Every DLC adds something to the game both story and gameplay wise, and I whole heartedly recommend getting them all (or the Ultimate Edition) if you can.The other side of the story telling is more subtle than speaking to townsfolk and being explicitly told what’s going on. A lot of the locations in the game contain stories that you figure out, rather than being told. For example, I entered a motel room with a bunch of long dead skeletons, some guns and pre-war cash laying around. Some people would just loot the joint and move on, and that’s fine. Other people will look around and realise through the way the bodies and guns are positioned and seeing the pre-war money was leading back to a briefcase in the middle of the room, that a standoff after a bank heist took place in this room over 200 years ago. Bethesda put a lot of TLC and work into deliberately laying places out this way. It’s not just a random composition, there is a reason why everything is the way it is. You may think it’s a shame that so much work was put into things most players would miss, but I prefer the think that the fact that so many players miss it makes it much more special for the players that catch it.The voiceover work can be a bit hit and miss, with the stand out performances being Ron Pearlman’s narration and Liam Neeson as your dad. Everything else is ok, or sometimes outright embarrassing, but I suppose that’s fair enough given the sheer amount of people there are to converse with. Your character isn’t voice acted, which of course gives a lot more freedom to the writers regarding conversation options. The writing is the real star of the show in this game. The game also offers a couple interesting radio stations to listen to whilst you roam the wastes, but in a game as long as this you will run into a lot of recurring dialogue and music that unfortunately gets old fast.GRAPHICS AND PERFORAMANCEFallout 3 was released in 2008 and it shows. It is by no means an ugly game and the scale of the world definitely makes up for the lack of eye candy.  The scale of the world also results in lots and lots of bugs. Some can be game breaking (albeit rarely) and others are just irritating or sometimes humorous. Ultimately I would say it’s worth powering through them to play the game. The game also has some major stability issues, especially on newer hardware. For instance I was having issues because for some reason this game was having issues with an OS newer than Vista and a processor with more than two cores. Almost everyone falls under that blanket these days and although these have easy fixes they are still annoying to deal with. The game used to have GFWL but thankfully it’s been removed. I would normally mitigate the ugliness of older games with mods, but I had issues with those here as well. Your mileage may vary, but I couldn’t go over 8-10 mods without constant crashing and FPS drops. In depth complicated mods are also much more annoying to install than something like Skyrim so I had to settle for more minor visual and quality of life changes.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Well, once again I haven't done the DLC (with the exception of Operation: Anchorage, which I liked; as a matter of fact, I haven't done the final ending choice for the main game because I'm waiting on Broken Steel), but I feel I've done enough to get the essential experience, as usual. Anyway, I'm going to do something different this time around and review this one twice, once as a game and once as a Fallout game, because THERE'S a contentious issue.As a game: It's a bit clunky, and the mechanics are often broken, but the story, atmosphere, characters, and immersion completely make up for it in a way that I've never seen before and almost didn't think possible. It was Yahtzee Croshaw that once said, "Immersion can save the life of a bad game, and inversely, a lack of immersion can be a dogshit bullet right between the eyes." I wouldn't call Fallout 3 a bad game, per se, but the flaws are clearly there. The weapon degredation isn't entirely necessary, as you'll run out of ammo far sooner than your gun will break, and there really aren't enough non-combat options for...anything, except getting bosses to stop being♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Overall, though, it completely sucked me in, and I highly recommend it to anyone who can handle what is probably the first game I've played that truly deserves an 'M' for Mature (as opposed to WHEE SHOOTY SHOOTY EXPLOSION).As a Fallout game: Let's start off with the good. With only one exception I can think of (the T-51b not being 'powered,' which I immediately created a mod to fix), it fits in with the lore perfectly, so no complaint there. In addition, it builds on the Fallout universe in a way that makes it seem even more truly alive, and does a lot with what already existed. I like what they did with Mr. Handys, Deathclaws, Harold's story, Fallout's trademark crazy people who'll start a cult over anything, the music (good God, I LOVE what they've done with the music), and several other elements. As for the bad, or what is popularly concieved as disowning it from the franchise: well, the tone is definitely shifted, into a more desperate, lonely experience, but people often forget how often that was often present in the first Fallout, too, what with the Glow, the invasion of Necropolis, the whole Boneyard situation, etc. Secondly, the gameplay is obviously completely different. It's certainly necessary for this particular game, but was it necessary for a new Fallout game? Countering a question with a question, is it really that different? You can still target individual parts of enemies, increase skills and earn perks, the SPECIAL system is still thankfully there, and you can get companions to help you out. Despite the 3D gameplay, this is still the same Fallout world with the same Fallout situations that you solve in the same Fallout ways. Yes, it is a Fallout game. I personally would put it below Fallout 1, but above Fallout 2. If you're an original Fallout fan, I recommend it even more.No, you want a game that seemingly will deviate to a large extent from the originals, look no further than Fallout 4...P.S. I find it interesting how Dogmeat shifted to a tank, instead of the ally who knocks enemies down so that you can get 95% criticals to their eyes. No complaints on the new version, though.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Honestly there isnt really much purpose to getting this game anymore since the game of the year edition was released. I bought it because it was on sale for like 2 bucks and regretted it later when I had to pay for all the DLC. The biggest problem with this release is it is buggy. It will not work on windows 8 or above, but If you look around online you can find numerous ways for you to be able to run the game by editing the files. Even after that expect occasional crashes. Other than that, this is easily the greatest game I have ever played. I have played it at least over 100 hours (I used the Fallout Script Extender so it wont actually log my hours on steam) and Where I usually lose interest in games after my second or third playthrough I have done at least 15 playthroughs of this game. This game allows you to1. Destroy the US government2. Nuke a developing city (or not but the explosion is pretty)3. Enslave people4. Find your dad5. Kill basically anyone (except for a very small number of essential characters)6. Join forces with a bunch of people.7. Roam a sizable game world at your own pace and do what you want. You can be a♥♥♥♥♥♥or you can be a saint, and the effects of your actions are felt.With the DLC you can1. Fight the chinese in a military simulation2. Be a slave in pittsburg3. Continue after the games ending and keep fighting the US government.4. Go to some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ island with nothing really there and a short, pointless quest.5. Get abducted by aliensThere is no reason not to buy this game. This game is the greatest fallout game in the series. Better than the originals, better than New Vegas, and still better than  Fallout 4. Also, you can get alot of mods for the game to customize your experience to your taste. I recommend 1.Enclave Improvement Project- Lets you join a group called the enclave you couldnt join in the main quest. 2. Sydney Follower mod- When you meet sydney in game, you will know why you need her as your follower.3.Ultimate Amata Follower mod- Amata is cool, and this is a good idea.4. Essential Followers- I dont know why the devs of this game want the followers to die. Get this and they wont. All of these mods are available on Nexus, a modding webside (its trustworthy, so you dont need to worry when you creat an account).

content:
Posted: January 6
												One of the Best Games I've ever played!Fallout 3 is my first Fallout game and I'm hooked into the series. Fallout 3 is great for FPS or RPG fans. This game has a great mix of Shooting, Exploring, and Story. Its so fun to discover new locations while leveling up and getting useful loot. I personally think the story is good, though the ending can be better. The best part of the game to me is building your character the way you want, there is no wrong way to pick your skills, just get what you wantIts definitly worth the price. If you plan on playing through this game, you HAVE to get the Broken Steal DLC. Read up on it, its a must have. Great value for your money with Fallout 3Only a few complaints, crashes are pretty common and the Frames aren't always smooth. But my issues within the actual game is the level cap of 30, and mediocre combat. None are gamebreaking to me, still a great experience(8/10) Classic game with minor issues, I highly recommend Fallout 3 to RPG and FPS players.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is one of the greatest games I've ever played.  The game world is huge, and there are tons of places to explore and things to see.  It's hard to put into words how tightly the elements of character, setting, and plot are woven together.  Discovering what has happened to humanity after the nuclear apocalypse is fantastically entertaining.  The controls are very easy to get used to, and what first looks like a complex inventory\status menu turns out to be quite simple and logical once you get the hang of it.  The choices you make have observable consequences, and you will more than likely develop real feelings toward some of the characters you meet, unless your heart is made of stone.  Regardless, exploring post-apocalyptic DC is a fantastic experience I would recommend to anyone.I purchased the game and all DLC for $7.24 and have played around 63 hours as of this edit.  This is a 10/10 game for sure.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												If you search a game to feel lying in a post-nuclear, chaotic and anarchic world, this game is yours. Or if you want an Oblivion or Skyrim with fire weapons, this game is yours too. Although the map isn't as big as Skyirm, it was a big one when it was released, and it has a lot of details that makes worth to spend time exploring it all.The history is great, and not only this major one. There are little histories inside the big one, details or personal messages of past wastelanders that immerses you even more inside the wasteland.The characters are great too.You can find evil persons, good persons, weird ones, etc... the world is still alive.  Dialogues are great and there many ways to bring a conversation. Also it has benefits if you choose certain options, so it's interesting to repeat to see how many possibilites are there. Also has dark humour and easter eggs. It's an open world, so you don't have to go just by one way, you can go wherever you want.The only bad thing i would say is that maybe there isn't much variety of weapons, specially on the melee field. Also the karma system is a little overbalanced, it's hard to be evil. Also, the level cap its at 20, but that is solved if you buy the DLC Broken Steel, which raises it to 30.9/10

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Like many of Bethesda's games, this is a masterpiece to say the least. The storyline is very engaging; you will get familiar with a lot of different characters, with thousands of different dialogue options, which also varies depending on your S.P.E.C.I.A.L. points, perks, and level of your skills. There is an abundance of weapons, and interesting items such as "bobbleheads" that you can find in various places to permanently increase your character's efficiency. I have lost count of how many different replays I've had on this game, and every single time it gets better. Now, I can't cram all of the amazing things about this game into a single review. It might be because I am too lazy, or because there is a character limit. However, I vivaciously encourage you to buy this one.

content:
Posted: January 2
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine  WAR, WAR NEVER CHANGES Fallout 3 is a game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks and is the third game in the Fallout franchise originally developed and published by Interplay. This is the first game in the series to go fully 3D from it's original top-down perspective and takes a more action orientation whilst still keeping the PRG elements from the first Fallout gamesI personally never liked the first Fallout games being Fallout, Fallout 2 and Fallout Tactics (which are on my GOG account) and I have only played so far with those games but with Fallout 3, I'm already hooked on the series. Its a perfect mix of RPG elements and FPS shooting, where its not complicated and fun to level upYou really get involved in the world and get into a routine of how to play, and the best part about it is, everyone's way to play the game will be different with the tons of options and choices you have offered to youThere are a few flaws, but nothing I think is game breaking. The framerate will drop at times, and crashes aren't uncommon. But the only thing I don't like about the actual games is the level cap. After level 30, I don't get as motivated to explore and do side questsAnd you will have a hell of a job trying to get this running on Windows 10, Windows 8/8.1 and Windows 7 but thankfully there are many tutorials to help you fix the compatibility issue Fallout 3 has with Windows 7 and up, just be careful when purchasingOverall though, Fallout 3 changed my views on the Fallout series and I can't wait to play the two other Fallout games being Fallout New Vegas and the recent installment by Bethesda being Fallout 4! RECOMMENDED :)

												Don't mind my hours here, I played on a modded version of the fallout which ment I had to have fose running (fallout luncher with modifications) Altough I have played this game on my PS3 console it was great fun to re-visit this game while it was on sale.It normally takes you 10 hours to complete the story with the main quest only, right ? *spoilers incoming*Well as I wanted to do some quests I started with the book of wasteland. On one of the ending quests we had to find ourselves in the "ship" city, which I had to walk to and you'll never guess what happened. I was walking by the pump rooms so I decided to go in, I killed a bunch of mutants and found some tapes, when I read them, my dad quest completed itself and it told me to go to vault 108. This skipped preatty much all of the finding bit and got me straight to the ending quests. I was rather dissapointed because it only took me like 5 hours to complete the game and if I ever wanted to do any sidequests, either I would have to load in the old save or start a new game.Overall I played fallout nv before and I have to say this is the better game, they both are perfectly fine and fun, but fallout nv took more of a "newbie" approach because the quests tell you exacly what to do and lead you exacly to the point, in fallout 3 oh no; its not as simple as that you have to do some searching around.Overall this game is amazing and i encourage people to do sidequests and not only the main story because you will be kind dissapointed with the lenght.

												ENGLISH VERSION FOLLOWS AFTER GREEK.Γράφω αυτό το review, όχι για το παιχνίδι αλλά για να ενθαρρύνω όποιον σκέφτεται να το πάρει αλλά φοβάται οτι δεν θα τρέχει σε win 10. Το αγόρασα προχθές σε win 10 και ενώ όπως λογικά λέει και στην κεντρική σελίδα δεν θα έπρεπε να τρέχει, μόλις έκανα διπλό κλικ για να ξεκινήσει, τα windows αυτόματα κατέβασαν το gfwl αρχείο (games for windows live) και εγώ απλά το εγκατέστησα. Απο κει και ύστερα το παιχνίδι τρέχει νερό χωρίς να χρειάζεται να ανοίγετε το gfwl. Όσον αφορά στο παιχνίδι τώρα, σίγουρα θα τα σπάει όπως και το New Vegas!This isn't a review about the game itself but my personal experience about it not being optimized for windows 10. After i downloaded it, i double clicked on the shortcut to run the game. Windows 10 informed me that this game isn't compatible with my current windows version and automatically downloaded gfwl.exe file. I just installed that file and since then the game works perfectly without modding anything at all. I hope i helped you clear any doubts about purchasing this great game!

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Personally this is my favourite game in the Fallout series as it covers and explains everything about the storyline. Sadly though i wasnt able to experience the second game of the franchise. I rarely found any bugs or glitches with this game and has replayability since you are always trying to discover new locations, characters, or enemies and go back and find little secrets hidden within the game or just to simply find things you havnt seen since you last played. Although even with this ther can tend to be small tiny glitches such as main characters your supposed to follow getting stuck in walls which makes you have to start from your recent save, but this rarely happens anyway. Even when you complete the storyline you can still explore these wastelands to find new side quest which are generally killing someone or just getting specific items. Bethesda really did a good job at making this brilliant game, Personally i would rate it 8/10 and would recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												I don't care what most people say - this game is so much better than New Vegas (not that I mind New Vegas all that much either). Why is it so much better? It's so creatively done; everything has this humorous quality to it; there are quaint little extra touches to be found everywhere. It's just so gloriously satisfying to be immersed in this world that has been so painstakingly put together just for your entertainment. The amusing little side stories that you uncover in this game can be quite hilarious (if you are anything at all like me then you can't stop yourself from snooping every email on every working terminal you happen to pass by). The characters can be so amusingly ridiculous at times that you just want to shoot them or worse yet set them loose in the desert to see how badly they fare. And some of the missions are just... Well, completely surprising. They can leave you scratching your head and wondering what the hell you should do, which way should you go? And I really love that! I never thought a game could be like that. And yet this one is. It will always be my absolute favourite.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Hi there! This game is Fallout 3, a post-apocalyptic game from the wonderful developers of Bethesda Softworks. This game is over 6 years old, but despite the short main story in the game, there's still a good amount of content to go about. The game world is open, the Capital Wasteland is inhabited by many things, some friendly but most things you'll meet are going to want to tear you apart and use your skull for decorating. But how about the DLC? Well I'll tell you. The only DLC that I have currently is called "Operation Anchorage", the story of the DLC is that in broad strokes you're helping fight the Red Chinese in the American Reconquest of Alaska, it gives you an insight into how a soldier lived before the Great War, daily putting his life at stake for the greater good of America, and the defense against Communism! You also need a DLC to continue playing after you continue the main storyline though... I don't know, I don't mind myself, but of course the DLC also gives you an expansion to the story, which I won't really go into, because it would spoil some... Things... Let's keep it at that, I guess you may have already had it spoiled anyways but I wouldn't wanna be the person that does it.Beware though, multiple people are complaining about the game being unstable on Windows 7 and even more so on 10 I've only had it crash twice, one being because I messed with the game files... I only had one glitch as well, and it wasn't gamebreaking.Questions I'd like to ask myself if I had no idea about Fallout:Q: Why wouldn't I buy Fallout 1 and 2 or Tactics first?A: You can do that, but the three first games are different to 3 and New Vegas in the sense that it's isometric top-down view in those games. There are also major graphical glitches on some system, but they should be fixable with an unofficial patch somewhere I believe... In comparison to newer Fallout games, which can be played either as 3rd person, or 1st person, I personally play as 1st person because it's more immersive.Q: Is there/what is the levelcap of Fallout 3 without any DLC and does DLC make a difference for the levelcap?A: In comparison to Fallout New Vegas where the levelcap can be 50 with all the DLC (30 without any at all) Fallout 3 only has a levelcap of 20, however this can be raised to 30 if you have the Broken Steel DLC, which is also the name of the DLC that allows you to play on after the end of the main Story.Q: What are the main differences between Fallout 3 and New Vegas?A: There's a number of them, mainly the factions system that they included in New Vegas, and also the removal of percentage chance to have a successful special dialogue option in favor for the more simple "Have X amount of points in Y skill, and you will be successful in this special dialogue." There are mods however, that allow you to switch it back I believe. Also that Fallout 3 by default has a color filter that makes everything look greener, whereas in New Vegas it makes the game look more orange-yellowy. There is a mod to turn this off called Fellout for both games, and I highly recommend it as I like being able to see specific colors instead of them being tinted either green or yellow. The locations are also vastly different as Fallout 3 takes place in the bombed ruins of Washington D.C and New Vegas takes place in the Mojave desert at Las Vegas (New Vegas in the game, surprise surprise) also the ability to disguise onself as a faction is New Vegas... It's something I don't really use but it can definitely be helpful in some situations, like when you don't wanna cause a shootout, and need to stay stealthy. This has been my review for Fallout 3 and I hope you liked it, patient reader. At first I thought I would just adress that the game is far from unplayable with Windows 7/10 as some people claim that it is, but it may vary from system to system I suppose.Thank you for reading, and I hope I convinced you somewhere along the way to buy Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												I didn't know what to expect when I heard the game known as Fallout. I remember my friends talking about Fallout 4, one of the lastest games in the series. I thought the concept of Fallout was astounding. Since I couldn't afford Fallout 4 at that time, I bought Fallout 3 to still enjoy the experience. May I be the first the say that I truely enjoyed this game and I never regretted buying this game. In my opinion, this is a masterpiece since this game actually got me into the franchise. Would I recommend getting this game? Yes, if you are new to Fallout and wanting to get into the series, even at a affordable price! Pros: If you are new to the Fallout series, get this game. It's not really my choice to tell you what Fallout game you should get to get into the franchise. For instance, you could probably get New Vegas or Fallout 4 if so, but this could be another choice to get into the series. One pro is that there is such a variety a choices that make a great impact on the game. This is a true RPG for creating your ideal character.Cons: I did meet some odd experiences so been cautioned when buying this game. The game is not compatable for Windows 7 and up, only for Windows Vista or below, however, this is an easy fix when researching how to configure Fallout 3 to Windows 7 and up. So it shouldn't be complex. On the side of that, I did experience some crashes eventually, but I'm assuming it was my computer since my computer has medium specs for gaming.For Pros and Cons, they're pretty even, I would recommend anyone getting into the Fallout series with this. Whether you want it or not, I still enjoyed it, thanks Bethesda! :)

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
ENGLISH and Italian Review Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA AWAY FROM HERE, BUY THE GAME OF THE YEAR EDITION!VIA DI QUI, COMPRA LA GAME OF THE YEAR EDITION!                                                  War... war never changes.English:Don't trust my gametime, i've bought this game on Steam too, just for collection. This game literally ruined my life, i've finished it like 14 times before losing the count. No, i'm not crazy, yes, my social life imploded. And don't trust the grandpas that will tell you this game is garbage just because they played the first 2 Fallouts and refused to play this one, they are just ignorant. In this game you live a wonderful and touching adventure in first person (Identifying so with the character), watching the character growing and becoming the hero or anti-hero that he'll be. Oh yes, because obviously you can and have to choose between choices that will influence the events and your karma. So, we have an abnormus replay factor, if we consider that we can play as good, bad, neutrals or do a mixed playtrough, choosing maybe a different type of class for the fight. AND, the game is easily moddable and has a large and active modding community: Nexus Mods. So, even if you have finished it in every way possible, you can mod it and transform it in a new game to discover. Trust me, this game is AWESOME.                                             La guerra... la guerra non cambia mai.Italiano:Non fidatevi del tempo di gioco che dice Steam, l'ho comprato anche qui giusto per averlo. Questo gioco ha letteralmente rovinato la mia vita, lo avrò finito qualcosa come 14 volte prima di perdere il conto. No, non sono pazzo, si, la mia vita sociale ne ha risentito un pochino. E non fidatevi dei vecchiacci che vi diranno che questo titolo fa schifo, solo perché giocarono ai primi due ai tempi, e si rifiutarono di giocare questo, sono degli ignoranti. In questo gioco vivi un'avventura stupenda e toccante in prima persona (Immedesimandoti dunque nel personaggio), vedendo il personaggio crescere man mano e plasmandolo lentamente nell'eroe o antieroe che sarà. Eh si, perché ovviamente potrai e dovrai fare delle scelte che influenzeranno gli eventi ed il tuo karma. Abbiamo dunque anche un fattore rigiocabilità enorme se consideriamo che possiamo giocare da cattivi, da buoni, da neutri o fare un mix, scegliendo magari anche una tipologia di personaggio diversa per quanto riguarda i combattimenti. Senza contare il fatto che il gioco è facilmente moddabile e vanta di una community di modders vasta e attiva, ovvero Nexus Mods. Dunque anche avendolo finito in tutte le maniere possibili e immaginabili, potete ancora moddarlo all'infinito e renderlo un gioco nuovo tutto da riscoprire. Fidatevi, questo gioco è perfetto.
