content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Good day once again close friends and strangers of the vast and dangerous internets, I have returned for another review. This time, of Fallout 3. Shall we get started?To start, I have to say I don't think I've ever experienced a more enjoyable character customisation than the one found in this game. It was full of humour and interesting choices (and said interesting choices often lead to more humour) and this theme continues throughout the duration of the game. Some notable choices include the chace to explode one of the only decent cities in the game, and the opportunity to commit genocide (that's going to remain without context; I don't want to spoil it for you). I honestly can't wait to jump back in and get back to making choices. CHOICES!!!!!!There's plenty of content in this game. In most of my reviews I mention that there's a need for extra content, or so much of the same type of content that it got stale but, much like the story of goldilocks, this bed was just right (How can a bed be too soft?!) I liked how the game was riddled with locked doors that could only be opened if you had a certain science or lock picking skillThe storyline was admirable, but not incredible. It basically consisted of "You're dad's gone missing, go find 'im" and then turns into "Genocide, yes or no?" However, I really did like the way the environment and various notes and computers could tell their own story and add depth to the game. Not enough games do this. The last of which that I've played was Mass Effect and before that, Skyrim (Both of these score a 10/10, btw)(Although, Mass Effect loses points for not publishing the third one on Steam) Often enough, reading journal entries could reveal more about what was actually going on in the environment. For example, in one particular moment, test chambers had dead mutated humans and, upon walking into these rooms, you could discover that they still contain radiation. This in itself mightn’t reveal much, but reading some journal entries shows who was responsible for these deaths (I shall say no more.)Now to mechanics. This game was built by Bethesda, so I thought I should mention that I noticed some similar mechanics in both of the games. However, obviously because this game is set in a post apocalyptic Washington D.C and not Viking Tamriel (And I'm not just saying that because of the helmets) There were some different and welcome variations between the two. For staters, the skill trees were far different. I actually liked the one in Fallout slightly (SLIIIIIIIGHTLY) better, although I can't really figure out why. However, I didn't really like how the currency in the game (Bottle caps) Were difficult to come by without performing getting bad karma (And I really wanted the good ending.) I honestly can't remember if I bought anything at all in this game. I just horded my caps until the end (Although, at times I wished I'd repaired my combat shotgun or purchased some health kits) For most weapons (All the weapons? I don't know, I didn't try them all out) There weren't any scopes, which made aiming excessively difficult. There was a cool system that allowed you to target a specific part of the body of your enemy and gave you a percentage chance of you hitting it. This was a great idea, but it was performed badly. A still, unaware target, regardless of the distance, should have a high percentage of hit. This wasn't always the case. Even a target standing 12 cm from your face only had a 95% chance of hit (SERIOUSLY, CHARACTER. DO YOU HAVE TOUURETTES?!) I would've disregarded this mechanic entirely except for the bonus critical chance it offers. The art style was good. I liked the way everything, even the towns, looked so make-shift and finding American monuments completely exploded was somewhat satisfying (I'm getting arrested for saying that, huh?) The graphics were decent, especially considering when this game was created.All right, let us summarise. Character customisation: GoodContent: ExcellentMechanics: SatisfactoryArt style: GoodI'm just about done. Final verdict- 8.3131932524020387829/10Thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: January 16
												A lot of games make a big deal out of player choice, but few in recent memory offer so many intricate, meaningful ways of approaching any given situation. You fulfill or dash the spiritual hopes of an idyllic society, side with slavers or their slaves, and decide the fate of more than one city over the course of your postapocalyptic journey through the Washington, DC wasteland. Your actions have far-reaching consequences that affect not just the world around you but also the way you play, and it's this freedom that makes Fallout 3 worth playing--and replaying. It's deep and mesmerizing, and though not as staggeringly broad as the developer's previous games, it's more focused and vividly realized.Welcome to the wasteland.Welcome to the wasteland.This focus is obvious from the first hour of the game, in which character creation and story exposition are beautifully woven together. It's an introduction best experienced on your own rather than described in detail here, but it does set up Fallout 3's framework: It's the year 2277, and you and your father are residents of Vault 101, one of many such constructs that shelter the earth's population from the dangers of postnuclear destruction. When dad escapes the vault without so much as a goodbye, you go off in search of him, only to find yourself snagged in a political and scientific tug of war that lets you change the course of the future. As you make your way through the decaying remnants of the District and its surrounding areas (you'll visit Arlington, Chevy Chase, and other suburban locales), you encounter passive-aggressive ghouls, a bumbling scientist, and an old Fallout friend named Harold who has, well, a lot on his mind. Another highlight is a diminutive collective of Lord of the Flies-esque refugees who reluctantly welcome you into their society, assuming that you play your cards right.The city is also one of Fallout 3's stars. It's a somber world out there, in which a crumbling Washington Monument stands watch over murky green puddles and lurching beasts called mirelurks. You'll discover new quests and characters while exploring, of course, but traversing the city is rewarding on its own, whether you decide to explore the back rooms of a cola factory or approach the heavily guarded steps of the Capitol building. In fact, though occasional silly asides and amusing dialogue provide some humorous respite, it's more serious than previous Fallout games. It even occasionally feels a bit stiff and sterile, thus diminishing the sense of emotional connection that would give some late-game decisions more poignancy. Additionally, the franchise's black humor is present but not nearly as prevalent, though Fallout 3 is still keenly aware of its roots. The haughty pseudogovernment called the Enclave and the freedom fighters known as the Brotherhood of Steel are still powerful forces, and the main story centers around concepts and objectives that Fallout purists will be familiar with.Although some of that trademark Bethesda brittleness hangs in the air, the mature dialogue (it's a bit unnerving but wholly authentic the first time you hear 8-year-olds muttering expletives) and pockets of backstory make for a compelling trek. There are more tidbits than you could possibly discover on a single play-through. For example, a skill perk (more on these later) will enable you to extract information from a lady of the evening, information that in turn sheds new light on a few characters--and lets you complete a story quest in an unexpected way. A mission to find a self-realized android may initiate a fascinating look at a futuristic Underground Railroad, but a little side gossiping might let you lie your way to quest completion. There aren't as many quests as you may expect, but their complexity can be astonishing. Just be sure to explore them fully before pushing the story forward: Once it ends, the game is over, which means that you'll need to revert to an earlier saved game if you intend to explore once you finishe the main quest.Thus choices are ruled only by your own sense of propriety and the impending results. For every "bad" decision you make (break into someone's room, sacrifice a soldier to save your own hide), your karma goes down; if you do something "good" (find a home for an orphan, give water to a beggar), your karma goes up. These situations trigger more consequences: Dialogue choices open up, others close off, and your reputation will delight some while antagonizing others. For example, a mutant with a heart of gold will join you as a party member, but only if your karma is high enough, whereas a brigand requires you to be on the heartless side. Even in the last moments of the game, you are making important choices that will be recounted to you during the ending scene, similar to the endings in the previous Fallout games. There are loads of different ending sequences depending on how you completed various quests, and the way they are patched together into a cohesive epilogue is pretty clever.Fallout 3 remains true to the series’ character development system, using a similar system of attributes, skills, and perks, including the S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system from previous games for your attributes, such as strength, perception, and endurance. From there, you can specialize in a number of skills, from heavy weapons and lock-picking to item repairing and terminal hacking. You will further invest in these skills each time you level, and you'll also choose an additional perk. Perks offer a number of varied enhancements that can be both incredibly helpful and a bit creepy. You could go for the ladykiller perk, which opens up dialogue options with some women and makes others easier to slay. Or the cannibal perk, which lets you feed off of fallen enemies to regain health at the risk of grossing out anyone who glimpses this particularly nasty habit. Not all of them are so dramatic, but they're important aspects of character development that can create fascinating new options.The VATS system makes for some awesome-looking battles.The VATS system makes for some awesome-looking battles.Although you can play from an odd-looking third-person perspective (your avatar looks like he or she is skating over the terrain), Fallout 3 is best played from a first-person view. Where combat is concerned, you will play much of the game as if it is a first-person shooter, though awkwardly slow movement and camera speeds mean that you'll never confuse it for a true FPS. Armed with any number of ranged and melee weapons, you can bash and shoot attacking dogs and random raiders in a traditional manner. Yet even with its slight clunkiness, combat is satisfying. Shotguns (including the awesome sawed-off variant) have a lot of oomph, plasma rifles leave behind a nice pile of goo, and hammering a mutant's head with the giant and cumbersome supersledge feels momentously brutal. Just be prepared to maintain these implements of death: Weapons and armor will gradually lose effectiveness and need repairing. You can take them to a specialist for fixing, but you can also repair them yourself, as long as you have another of the same item. It's heartbreaking to break a favored weapon while fending off supermutants, but it reinforces the notion that everything you do in Fallout 3, even shooting your laser pistol, has consequences. No matter what platform you own, you should play Fallout 3, which overcomes its issues by offering a deep and involving journey through a world that's hard to forget. It has more in common with Bethesda's Elder Scrolls series than with previous Fallout games, but that is by no means a bad thing. In fact, Fallout 3 is leaner and meaner than Bethesda's previous efforts, less expansive but more intense, while still offering immense replay value and quite a few thrills along the way.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
 First Thoughts "This game looks a little weird"(=)"The art style and direction is pretty awesome though"(+)"Lots of easily added mods"(+)"Atmosphere is amazing!"(+)"What day is it...?"(+++) Review Fallout 3 has to be one of the best Open World RPGs I've ever played and has to be one of my favorite games. Now I know what you're thinking and before you say anything about how long I've played, but I owned the game on xbox before rebuying it because it's just that great of a game. This game has one of the best post apocolyptic setting and style I've ever seen.The game play is obviously like any RPG made by Bethesda. You can really get a feel for your character and have relativly nice control over who they are, even if it's all put on a morality system that sometimes can be a little off. The situations you're put into have multiple outcomes and ways of going about them and the game gives you a sizeable amount of freedom without giving you everything. The combat and weapon variety is awesome, even if some weapons are better than others. If you are really committed to having your character be a certain way, you have all the freedom to do it and the tools available. It really is a game where you can get a feel for how you want to do something. And the large modding community this game had gives this game even more replay value because mods can add so much more to this game.Now there will always be obvious problems in these games. While the game is mostly great, you will experience your occasional bug but that is pretty standard with Bethesda RPGs. And the fact that when you try and zoom in with a weapon, it just ZOOMS in was a pretty bad choice(which I'm glad can be fixed with mods and that Bethesda later chose to change for Fallout: NV). Also that third person was also a little weird. While I'm sure some people may have enjoyed it, I usually stayed with first person. I think this could've been fixed if you had more control over where your character was located(I.E. To the right, left or centered). The game is also EXTREMELY easy if you're a thief. You actually have to force yourself into not being successful because it's too easy to be successful in this game. But all and all, I recommend this game to EVERYONE who even has a slight interest in trying it because it's an experience that isn't worth missing out on.  Also get The Pitt. BEST DLC FOR THIS GAME EVVVVVEEEEERRRRR	  Final Verdict: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												(contains spoilers)when i first played fallout 3, i played for an entire weekend. sure it has bugs and quirks, but it's engrossing and immersive. and sure, i could patch it to fix the bugs, but in the hundred or more hours i've played it (not just on steam) i couldn't be bothered. this is one game which allows you to do the following things (spoilers): go on a peyote trip to infiltrate a cult, and subsequently settle a 200 year old blood feud between a mutated congressman and a disembodied brain. get abducted by aliens and violently commandeer their ship with the help of a 70 year old child, a cowboy, a samurai, a US army medic, and one dead astrnaut. break your legs and irradiate yourself... for SCIENCE! lead a communist rebellion that goes about exactly the way of the trotskyites'. enter into the simulation of an idyllic 50's picket fence neighborhood and torture people at the behest of a mad scientist disguised as a little girl. helping Liam Neeson water the collective lawns of every dead person in the united states, and during all of this, i honestly couldn't tell you where anything had changed along the ride, because i was still systematically painting walls red with an arsenal of weapons just varied enough to be interesting, and not so varied as to bog itself down. is it perfect? no, not even close. but the full DLC pack is $20 on steam and i guaruntee you will never get the same amount of joy for 20 bucks at an arcade, even a Live Arcadein a Boxwit an "X" on itrudding buy this thing! it will ruin your life for the better.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												The game is pretty good.  Story-wise... not so much. The original Fallout is way better in that regard. But in any other aspect is a superior game and quite fun. I played this with a vista PC, so I had no problems as people with newer PCs. Still I had a few crashes, very few. By the way, is really desirable to get the Broken Steel DLC. It allows you to keep playing after the end of the regular Fallout. It is a must if you like to do everything in a game. Or skip this one and get the GOTY edition that is complete. It´s a dystopian world, be a saint, be an evil-doer, shot your way all across the wasteland. At the end you'll always find the path that suit your personality. Just don't get too attached to any person, you might need to kill him or her later. And maybe you'll enjoy that after all.All in all is a great gaming experience.

												I first played this game when it came out for xbox and I can honestly say it is the best game I have ever played in my life.  I originally paid 50 bucks when it came out for xbox but i purchased this pc version for about 6 bucks.  the best money ever spent.Where else can you use a nuke to blow up a whole city and get paid for it with bottle caps and a free deluxe apartment? The game is still worth it to play though because the crashes happen only every so often.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Ok so I was playing Fallout 3 on PS3 24/7 until I mastered it. It was on the summer holidays last year and I spent the whole summer mastering the game . I found everything that there is in it . Damn nostalgia striked when I hear Three Dog on the radio saying "THIS IS THREE DOG , AUUUU AND YOU ARE LISTENING TO GALAXY NEWS RADIO" . Damn. So I was playing it for 18 hours straight and I finished the game. My goal now is to master it all over again on the PC. But I got to admit. Console version is♥♥♥♥♥♥compared to the PC version of the game. FPS , graphics everything looks better on the PC. And + there are no problems like game quits for no reason or freezes after playing for several hours. That happened to the PS3 version a lot and it's broken so I am glad they fixed that on the PC version. The game offers you over 100 hours of gameplay and I am looking forward to buy the DLC's so I can expand it even more. It's just sad *SPOILER ALERT* when you die at the end of the game, but you don't if you own the DLC called Broken Steel. Fear, courage,adventure,shooter almost everything is mixed up in this game. It's one of the best games that exists and I recommend it to everyone out there. FOR  ALL APOCALYPSE FANS -----> "COURAGE TODAY, VICTORY TOMORROW !"

content:
Posted: September 20, 2011
												Quite possibly the best RPG ever made; Fallout 3 does what other sandbox RPG games attempt to do; create an enormous open world mixed with an immersive story and interesting characters. Decided to be good or bad, the world is filled with interesting quests that wont let you stop playing. The biggest draw is exploration; how Washington DC looks after a large scale nuclear war, visiting new markers on your map and fighting off enemies or helping random civilians. I was skeptical at first, Fallout 3 takes a bit to get going, but once youre committed Fallout 3 will not disappoint. I promise you that.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Fallout 3, is probaly one of the best RPG's i have ever played, but it's not for everyone, this game is hard to get into, you need to put some hours into the game before it starts to get fun, not only that the game might not be your typical run and gun FPS. i would say as a warning for people with Windows 7/8/8.1, that game has alot of problems, since it was for Windows XP, there are game bugs, most of whom can be fixed. But why is Fallout 3 good? Fallout 3 is a prime exampel of an RPG done right, the game is filled with to the brim with Story, not only that, but there is so much to explore in fallout 3, the music in Fallout 3 fits so perfect with the theme of the game, the gameplay is hard as ♥♥♥♥ but, but fun as ♥♥♥♥, the game is just fun, this is a must buy for RPG lovers9,5/10

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Let me just start off by saying that I purchased this for $2.49 on the Steam Summer Sale of 2015 and I have enjoyed this game very much. Even though this game may show its age (It is from 2008 after all) and may have bugs/incompatibility this is still a fantastic RPG, inside and out. If you are a graphics snob like me I highly suggest you install some graphical tweaks from Fallout Nexus, they revive the game and make it look like it was straight out of 2015. There is so much to be said about this game but I would rather have you experience it for your self, its $10 on the store and honestly I would pick up this game again and again if I could.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2011
												Fallout 3 is a sandbox RPG from the people who brought you Oblivion, and like Oblivion, it has ups and downs. The ups are decent graphics, good balance and gameplay, decent voice acting and quests, while the downs are crashes and graphical errors, horrible animations, weak level perks, and to be honest? Not much replayability. Yeah you can choose different outcomes for quests, or wield different weapons, but attention isn't given enough to the different styles (melee, ranged, unarmed) to warrant playing out different characters.But this is just my opinion. I still say this is a fantastic game despite its flaws, and worth buying. The encounters, both scripted and unscripted, are fun, plain and simple. There's plenty to explore and amusing scenarios to play over and over quickly via the quicksave and quickload, which is instant, unlike other games. The AI is decent, funny, and makes for interesting scenarios. As a standalone game it's worth the investment, just dont expect perfection. 8/10

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Except with the downside of it not being compatible with Windows 8 it is possibly one of the best games of all time. New Vegas may have polished what Fallout 3 lacked but Fallout 3 has such a different and unique atmosphere from NV. I will not give any spoilers as to what happens during the game in this review so don't worry. The game really does capture you from the start and transport you all the way to the end which is amazingly well done. You will begin to feel for the characters that you encounter and if they so happen to die you'll actually care unlike some other games. The gameplay is obviously from a FPS perspective and it is an new feature added that wasn't in the previous games. The open world element to the game is suited to the game and exploration is encouraged throughout it. The graphics may seem slightly dated but that is hardly noticable when you immerse yourself in this expansive world of post-apocalyptic Washington DC. Overall I give this game a 8.5/10 an amazing game that revived the franchise.

content:
Posted: April 17
 Daddy issues. Fallout 3 is daddy issues the game. Fallout 3 is a great game. The base game is fluent, fun and glitchy as hell (In a great, not ♥♥♥♥ing the game way) which is brilliant. The story of Fallout 3 is simple, but great at the same time and the DLC increase this in great leagues while also mostly not linking to the main story, excluding the story extending DLC, however the mods extend this futher. The modding community of Bethesda games are among the greatest, if not the greatest. Although, as it is with most Bethesda games, once everything is done, there is nothing to keep you interested, this is the one problem I can see with this game in the aspect of gameplay. If you've come from console onto PC and are thinking of getting this game again, get it. Just the mods alone can increase the fun you can get out of Fallout ten fold, so just the mods alone are worth it, I'd recommend this game to basically anyone, from people just starting on PC and veterans alike.   -Englishman 8/10

Primarily step 6 did the trick for me (which links to an unofficial patch that really does fix everything for you) and I played the game until the end without a single crash.

Posted: March 12, 2014
 WARNING THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS Fallout 3 has to be in my top 5 games of all time, It has such a amazing story and gameplay. Huge variety of weapons and the map is massive, You will never run out of missions or places to explore. Basicly you wonder a awesome wasteland listening to great 30's and 40's music. Starting with old wornout rifles and revolvers working your way up to lazer rifles and plasma casters, And starting with old dusty coats and a jumpsuit from when you were in a vault to beast power armor 'Some with tesla coils on them'... There is so many ways to play this game. You could be a good Samaritan and help everybody out and people would recognize that.. Or you could be the opposite of that and not help people.. Kill innocent's. and people would recognize that also.Overall score:Story ~ 9/10 'Will keep you interested, Alot of thought'Graphics ~ 6.5/10 'They aren't bad just nothing to brag about'Physics ~ 5/10 'Just your average grade, You can pick up items though'Replayability ~ 10/10 'I could play this game again no questions asked, I've finished it probably 10 times' p.s. Liam Neeson is your father

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Fallout 3 was a great game when it was new, and thanks to the power of mods, this game is just as good today (2015). Mods have updated the visuals, effects, and content of the game to feel like it's brand new.Everywhere you go, there is a town or person that needs to be saved, and you are that person who can save everyone... or not. While this game doesn't offer as much freedom of choice that New Vegas offers, Fallout 3 gives you many opportunities to feel like a hero in various ways. Newer games tend to throw side-quests at you so you can get detoured for hours doing a lot of them. Fallout 3's story progresses in a very linear fashion, and while there are many sidequests that you can partake in, you often have to go out of your way to find and solve these quests. You can very realistically go from the beginning to end of this game without doing one sidequest. It's not a bad thing, but it does make this game less immersive than more recent games of this type.If you've never played Fallout 3 before, this is definitely one worth playing as it set the bar for other amazing games in the genre.8/10 "Great"

You can play through Fallout 3 and Fallout 4 and still consider them completely separate games.Truly, if you want to play Fallout 4 play Fallout 4. If you want to play Fallout 3, play Fallout 3.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												After finally finishing Fallout 3 (which my hours aren't actually recorded on Steam which annoys me), I feel like now I can finally write a review about how I feel for this game:In the beginning, I felt like I was going to get bored of this game cause I didn't enjoy the Vault 101 part a lot. But after a while, I enjoyed the game a lot.The game's difficult, it has a nice atmosphere, the story's great and the characters are pretty good in terms of personality. Hell, I even got scared sh*tless when I was encountering some enemies in the night and inside some buildings.However, I do think that the main story was a bit short but I found it enjoyable nonetheless. I get it that you can continue your story with the Broken Steel DLC but I don't really have it, that's why it was short for me. And as for the notice, yes. It's not optimized for Windows 7 and later since it wasn't working at the beginning, but after watching a guide of how to make it work on Youtube, it took me like a few minutes to make it work. Not a very big deal.Overall, Fallout 3 is not my favorite Fallout game but it's surely one of my favorite games. I can fully recommend this game. And if you have a potato PC like I do, then don't worry. The game was running with like 30 FPS and I had a nice time.P.S.: That f*cking behemoth in the beginning, though. I wasn't expecting that at all. ;-; Also, I can't believe there's a weapon called "Fat man" lol.

												Iam a big fan of Fallout 1 and 2 and Iam glad I've seen at least one character from the old games; But a few Fallout fans and friends of mine told me not to waste time on this game and skip to the Last Vegas.But I gave it a shot and I say it is not so bad. Well the beginning is amusingly ridiculous when they act with you like with infant and literally, but it made me laugh and it is really nice to see power armor animated in full 3D model.The gameplay is pretty much like Oblivion, it is pretty obvious that is from the same creators.If you dont mind it you can play it. If you dont like oblivion style gaming, you can still play old 1 or 2 if you didnt played it yet.But what I really cant swallow is the ending, which is pretty linear and very "hero" like. And hero like I mean stupid as hell.I would push the NO recommend button just because of that lame and corny ending, but luckily you can go ahead and download mod alternate ending, or just forget the main line and just enjoy those few side quests which are pretty fun.And for the first start, the best option is always set inteligence to 9 and google info about bobbleheads.Oh and if you'll meet Uncle Leo send him regards by me!

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												How to fix freezes/crashes on Windows 7 or above.Go to documents/my games/Fallout3Click FALLOUT.ini or just FALLOUT if the .ini isn't present.Edit it with notepad or notepad++. Press control+F and type "bUseThreadedAI"It will say bUseThreadedAI=0, change the 0 to a 1.Press enter and type EXACTLY this: iNumHWThreads=2Save the file.Boot up Fallout 3, than ALT+TAB out.Open task manager and look for Fallout3.Right click it and go to properties.Up the top, press compatibilty.Than, select what operating system you have.I hope this helped!

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
-Quick Review-Fallout 3 is large open world FPS-RPG which takes the narrative of "what would happen if there had been a nuclear exchange in the 1940's and the citizens of the United States was trying to struggle with the after math of a nuclear exchange". Developed by everyone's favorite open world developers Bethesda Game Studios and released in 2008.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: Welcome to Vaunt 101, while there aren't any Vault Hunters searching for it (Ha, Borderlands cross over review joke) there are quite a number of treasures to be found within this vault. The Vault was designed to house and take care of it's inhabitants in the aftermath of a nuclear holocaust.You spend a good chunk of time learning about vaunt 101, meeting the other citizens, and growing up. Literally, you start as a baby being born in vault 101, then as you grow up you learn more about core mechanics within the Fallout 3 game, ethics, V.A.T.S., S.P.E.C.I.A.L., combat, and more!The games story really doesn't start until your father suddenly disappears and you go searching for him! I won't spoil anything else about the story, but it does go on for quite a while, as you would expect and hope for in a Bethesda game!*Hardware: "Notice: Fallout 3 is not optimized for Windows 7 and later" EHHHHHHHhhhhhhhh..... My brother and I had to tinker with the files and do some trouble shooting to get it to work on my windows 7 computer in 2015. Then I directly transferred the game data to my new Windows 10 Computer Rig.I can say we got it to work, however I cannot say for certain if any changes were made that would allow you to simply download from steam and get the game working. I can say that right now with the changes we made it works on windows 7 and 10.


One of these things is not like the other! 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: Wheeeew, where to start? Lets start with the simple first: Fallout 3 controls like a FPS, I trust 99% of the people reading this review understand what direction to point the gun and click to KA-BOOM. (If you don't, I'll just file that under "troll")Next to explain V.A.T.S., the game probably will do a better job of explaining it, but V.A.T.S. stand for "Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System", and will allow you to pause the game, and take aim for you at a specific part of an enemy. But hitting your target is based on percentages, so if you shoot at point blank and have a 99% chance of hitting your target, there's always that 1% chance you'll miss.Since my luck is terrible, I tend to try to avoid using VATS, but over stream someone pointed out I could use them for explosive weapons and grenades, since I particularly STINK at hitting my target when I'm throwing a grande.Next we move on to S.P.E.C.I.A.L.! S.P.E.C.I.A.L. is an acronym for the primary attributes in Fallout3. They stand for: Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility and Luck. (This is pretty standard for RPG's, so I'm going to move on, but if you need a better explanation, feel free to leave a comment!)All the other qualities of the game can be broken down into the "par for the course" as far as RPG's and Open World games are concerned. Expect a lot of exploration, expect gear with different perks, expect optimization strategies online; explaining where to go and how to play.Something I didn't expect was: Fallout 3 is hard! I fancy myself an average skilled gamer (I play medium difficulty with ease normally), I'm constantly eating Stimpack for breakfast while I play (Stimpack = healing item). I've sunk a crazy amount of caps (that's the currency by the way) into hoarding Stimpacks, I'm like a doctor or someone doing illegal drug related stuff.Achievements: At this time there aren't any steam achievements for Fallout3, this may change someday, depending on if Bethesda decides to add achievements. (They have achievements for Skyrim, and Fallout4, but those were available at launch.)


fisty cuffs him daaaaad! 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3
By: Atratzu




Price: Fallout3 is priced at $9.99, the Game of the Year Edition is priced at $19.99. You'll get more mileage (almost literally, ha!) out of your game by purchasing the the Game of the Year Edition. Over twitch someone suggested I play through the DLC to get power armor, and it would make the rest of the play through easier.Conclusion: Fallout 3 is to some, what Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is to me; a wonderful game that opened them up to the amazing size and scope a game can actually be. While I will always personally prefer Oblivion, I have enjoyed playing through this game, and can easily recommend it to anyone who's even remotely interested. Fallout 3 is totally worth your time.I recommend this game to anyone whom enjoys a challenge, likes Open World games, mods, enjoys RPG's, isn't intimidated by large open spaces, and has A LOT of free time to explore.Thanks for reading my review!


More Gnome Nonsense. Why do these always amuse me? (I need to buy one IRL) 
A Screenshot of Fallout 3
By: Atratzu




*The Hardware part of this review was added specifically for Fallout 3 and isn't a regular Atratzu Review critique of games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I could make a joke about this game then say "10/10" at the end, but I believe this game deserves more than that.This game is absolutely incredible, anyone who says its anything less of a masterpiece is mentally handicapped.First of all, the area to explore is massive, I have over 200+ hours on it (I played a lot of it while on offline mode, so the hours on my account don't show the full amount) and I still havn't gotten around to looking over all of the areas.Second of all, the quests are amazing. Starting off with the main story, it is incredibly fun. From starting as a kid in the vault to fighting off the Enclave forces alongside a gigantic robot named Liberty Prime, it is a non-stop good time.As for the DLC's, most are equally incredible. Broken Steel, The Pitt, and Point Lookout are all amazing to say the least. While Broken Steel adds onto the main story and raises the level cap, The Pitt and Point Lookout give you entirely new quests and areas to explore, both of which are awesome. To a lesser extent, Operation Anchorage and Mothership Zeta are both somewhat decent addons, but failed to meet my expectations. Operation Anchorage was very short, I finished it in about 2 hours without rushing it, and Mothership Zeta was incredibly repetative and dont even get me started on what it attempted to do to the Lore.Alongside the Main Quests and DLC's, many of the side quests are also fantastic. One that really caught me off guard was a short little quest called "Oasis" in which after exploring the dull wasteland, you find yourself in a lush green paradise, where you meet a mutated man-turned-tree named Harold. The story is quite interesting, and depending on which ending you chose, can leave you quite upset.Now lets talk about the graphics. Yes this game is a bit outdated, but I for one think it looks fairly decent, and still hold up to some games today. As for the textures, they are quite flat, but I dont think you will really be paying attention to that while your gunning your way through hordes of Super Mutants and Ghouls.The enemies in this game are also amazing. There are plenty of enemies scattered across the Capitol Wasteland, from little pests like Radroaches and Bloatflies to the incredibly strong Deathclaws and Super Mutant Behemoths, there is little time to sit around a campfire and sing ballads about your fallen comrads before a gang of Raiders come to ruin your good time.These Raiders wont be much trouble however if your properly equiped. This game comes with a bunch of weapons which are all fun to use, such as the Combat Shotgun, the Hunting Rifle, and everyones favourite, the Fat Man. Most of these weapons also come with one or more "Unique" variations, which usually grant higher damage or special abilities, all of which are very useful when things start to get a little rough.Lastly, entertainment. I am not stretching this at all, and I dont think what Im about to say will change anytime soon. This game is the best game I have ever played. It is absolutely insane how good this game is. If I could play only 1 game for the rest of my life, it would be this. The story is great, the graphics are good, the area to explore is huge, the enemies are awesome, the replayability is off the charts, and if you ever start to get bored, a quick look over at the Nexus will keep you playing for hours on end. Now that ive said all this, I can honestly say...420/69

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												When I played Fallout 3 for the first time I was really amazed. The game seemed great and I enjoyed playing it. Of course, when you play a game like this one for some time it is not as interesting as it was.What I like about the game:1. The atmosphere. It is a real fun. You can blow up raiders and supermutants listening to some kind song about love.2. A promising start. At the beginning of the game I felt like there was going to be something epic.3. Hacking, lock-picking, speech. It's great when you can solve your problems this way.4. Using different weapons. In most RPGs you pick some kind of weapon and stick to it. In Fallout 3 I used nearly all weapons because you never know what ammo you're going to find.*** SPOILER ***5. Blowing up Megaton. The quest is stupid, but it is fun, plus you get a better apartment on the top of the tower for doing this.6. Quests. Specially the Vault where you find your father in.What I don't like about the game:1. The ending. It is not epic at all. The final battle is epic, but not the ending. I just wanted to try my new armor and weapons which I got from the final battle, but I could not because the game ended. It's they allowed to continue the game by purchasing The Broken Steel.2. Hacking and science. In my opinion hacking could have been more sophisticated. And science skill is responsible only for hacking.3. Characters and quests. They are great mostly, the bad thing is that no matter what character you are playing you are always treated the same. There are minor differences like Sir, Madam depending on gender, some options depend on your karma and some perks add some options to the dialogs. But that is nothing comparing to the previous games of Fallout where you are treated like and idiot because your intelligence is 1.I would give this game 8/10

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												What would happpen if the pre-modern times cold war went full-on hot? Fallout 3, minus any survivors of course. This game has such a unique setting and characters that it's hard to compare with any other title, however, it has its own flaws.Pros:-Good story.-Excellent character acting, for an open world that is.-Incredibly well detailed open world. I think that the world looks like as if every meter of it is unique.-Hours of fun.Cons:-Terrible ending, I mean, I do get the ending cinematics, but why would anyone make a game so rich in content and incredibly well detailed scenery and not let the player explore this after the main quest end? I managed to explore only about 30% of the game world before I remembered the ending sucks. And I sure ain't planning on replaying this for the 3rd time.-Bias, sure it's a fantasy post-war game, but the amount of cheesy bias in the storyline specially near the ending with Libery Prime spewing crapware about how democracy is not negotiable or commies must die (In this case blaming China and Russia for anexing Alaska which was actually anexed by fallen UN in the game lol) and the worst of all for the game creator, making the founding fathers of true America tyrants and "robots" who want to kill all humanity and act as secret organisation when in reality the Lyions (in the game) and Palladins (in the game) are the actual bad guys who want mutants and all sorts of unhumanly creatures multiplied and over Capital Wasteland (Washington D.C.) to repopulate the Earth.Conclusion:I bought this game on Steam again only for the sake of good old days when games were fun, and replaying Fallout 3 I realised how many things I missed back in the day when I first played this game. Needless to say that if it wasn't for the unique setting, open world characters like in no other game and detail in the terrain, I would of never played this game in the first place, specially with the ending and bias in storyline that surely ruined what could of been the best open world game ever made to this day.So should you buy it? If you've played it, only if on sale, if not then give it a try.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												My review for Fallout 3! (And my Pros/Cons)PROS:Hundreds of hours of epic gameplay in the Capital Wasteland!With DLC's about 50+ hours at least (plus new perks, weapons, enemies, quests, and other stuff)Varied terrain, enemies, weapons, quests, armor, perks, and other itemsCrafting/repair systemGame that is open-worldGraphics are phenomenal for its timeKarma SystemCONS:After completing largely everything in the game its hard to play again (can get sick of playing too much)Graphics need reworking (in my opinion)Some weapons largely have no effect on enemies Pistols in game need to be completely re-worked (e.g. sights, recoil, damage, animations sometimes)Some quests are variations of each otherIf you dont like large games you wont like thisGame might erase your saveThere are certain enemy and graphics glitches that are known to happenOVERALL: This game is revolutionary! I highly recommend this title to every gamer! Even though my CONS outweigh my PROS I still believe this game is still very good but with limited replay. 9/10(Anyone who wants to friend me do so but I might reject your request)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I could make a joke about this game then say "10/10" at the end, but I believe this game deserves more than that.This game is absolutely incredible, anyone who says its anything less of a masterpiece is mentally handicapped.First of all, the area to explore is massive, I have over 200+ hours on it (I played a lot of it while on offline mode, so the hours on my account don't show the full amount) and I still havn't gotten around to looking over all of the areas.Second of all, the quests are amazing. Starting off with the main story, it is incredibly fun. From starting as a kid in the vault to fighting off the Enclave forces alongside a gigantic robot named Liberty Prime, it is a non-stop good time.As for the DLC's, most are equally incredible. Broken Steel, The Pitt, and Point Lookout are all amazing to say the least. While Broken Steel adds onto the main story and raises the level cap, The Pitt and Point Lookout give you entirely new quests and areas to explore, both of which are awesome. To a lesser extent, Operation Anchorage and Mothership Zeta are both somewhat decent addons, but failed to meet my expectations. Operation Anchorage was very short, I finished it in about 2 hours without rushing it, and Mothership Zeta was incredibly repetative and dont even get me started on what it attempted to do to the Lore.Alongside the Main Quests and DLC's, many of the side quests are also fantastic. One that really caught me off guard was a short little quest called "Oasis" in which after exploring the dull wasteland, you find yourself in a lush green paradise, where you meet a mutated man-turned-tree named Harold. The story is quite interesting, and depending on which ending you chose, can leave you quite upset.Now lets talk about the graphics. Yes this game is a bit outdated, but I for one think it looks fairly decent, and still hold up to some games today. As for the textures, they are quite flat, but I dont think you will really be paying attention to that while your gunning your way through hordes of Super Mutants and Ghouls.The enemies in this game are also amazing. There are plenty of enemies scattered across the Capitol Wasteland, from little pests like Radroaches and Bloatflies to the incredibly strong Deathclaws and Super Mutant Behemoths, there is little time to sit around a campfire and sing ballads about your fallen comrads before a gang of Raiders come to ruin your good time.These Raiders wont be much trouble however if your properly equiped. This game comes with a bunch of weapons which are all fun to use, such as the Combat Shotgun, the Hunting Rifle, and everyones favourite, the Fat Man. Most of these weapons also come with one or more "Unique" variations, which usually grant higher damage or special abilities, all of which are very useful when things start to get a little rough.Lastly, entertainment. I am not stretching this at all, and I dont think what Im about to say will change anytime soon. This game is the best game I have ever played. It is absolutely insane how good this game is. If I could play only 1 game for the rest of my life, it would be this. The story is great, the graphics are good, the area to explore is huge, the enemies are awesome, the replayability is off the charts, and if you ever start to get bored, a quick look over at the Nexus will keep you playing for hours on end. Now that ive said all this, I can honestly say...420/69

												People of the wasteland listen! This game was NOT designed for windows 7 OR 8. unfortunatly i run on a windows 8 x64bit operating system so it was extremly difficult to get this game to run. If you do have windows 7 or 8 which most of you will, be ready to spend ALOT of time modding the games codeing and software to get it to work. PC is alot more fun with mods, console commands ECT, but consoles are guaranteed to run it. And also before you all blame the creators its not Bethesda's fault! We must remember this game was released in 2008 before windows 7 so it would have never been possible to update it to run properly for windows 7 or 8.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												...Damn son, they say Fallout New Vegas and Skyrim is better than Fallout 3. If that's the case, they must be beyond awesome. Fallout 3 with Broken Steel, as far as I'm concerned, is one of the best games I've ever played. Bethesda manages to blend the FPS, Open World, and RPG genres very, very, well. Mechanically, it is incredible!PROS:-SHOULDER MOUNTED NUKES-Really awesome original score of ambient, and a selection of music from the 40s.-An incredible and very large world. I'm especially a fan of the DC area.-Interesting way they use RPG elements through their statistic systems of SPECIAL, Perks, and the many skills.-Everything is trying to kill you. But overtime, you can gain this incredible arsenal that makes you feel really awesome.CONS:-Notice I say it's good with BROKEN STEEL DLC. This is because the story is....questionable. Very questionable.-Sometimes the game is simply very jank with it's technicalities. The game just minimizes and I can't go back. Then there is the models in-game. But the latter isn't a big deal if you're not concerned with visuals.What can I say about Fallout 3 that hasn't already been said? 4/5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												What would happpen if the pre-modern times cold war went full-on hot? Fallout 3, minus any survivors of course. This game has such a unique setting and characters that it's hard to compare with any other title, however, it has its own flaws.Pros:-Good story.-Excellent character acting, for an open world that is.-Incredibly well detailed open world. I think that the world looks like as if every meter of it is unique.-Hours of fun.Cons:-Terrible ending, I mean, I do get the ending cinematics, but why would anyone make a game so rich in content and incredibly well detailed scenery and not let the player explore this after the main quest end? I managed to explore only about 30% of the game world before I remembered the ending sucks. And I sure ain't planning on replaying this for the 3rd time.-Bias, sure it's a fantasy post-war game, but the amount of cheesy bias in the storyline specially near the ending with Libery Prime spewing crapware about how democracy is not negotiable or commies must die (In this case blaming China and Russia for anexing Alaska which was actually anexed by fallen UN in the game lol) and the worst of all for the game creator, making the founding fathers of true America tyrants and "robots" who want to kill all humanity and act as secret organisation when in reality the Lyions (in the game) and Palladins (in the game) are the actual bad guys who want mutants and all sorts of unhumanly creatures multiplied and over Capital Wasteland (Washington D.C.) to repopulate the Earth.Conclusion:I bought this game on Steam again only for the sake of good old days when games were fun, and replaying Fallout 3 I realised how many things I missed back in the day when I first played this game. Needless to say that if it wasn't for the unique setting, open world characters like in no other game and detail in the terrain, I would of never played this game in the first place, specially with the ending and bias in storyline that surely ruined what could of been the best open world game ever made to this day.So should you buy it? If you've played it, only if on sale, if not then give it a try.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Fallout 3 is one of the best games, hands down. Most of my time playing it has been using modded alternate launchers, but I have spent well over 100 hours in-game. You can do whatever you want, it is completely non-linear, etc - pretty much Skyrim as a post-apocalyptic world. Once you have exhausted most of the content in the vanilla game (which will take hundreds of hours, depending on how you play) there are a ton of great mods on the Nexus. Especially for a $10 dollar game, this is one of the best things you could buy on Steam.

Posted: January 3, 2013
												One of the best games I have ever played. It was a hassle to set it up and get past countless startup bugs but it was worth it. Quests are varied and never boring, and the 50's era vibe it has going to it really enhances the story and atmosphere of the game. Combat could be improved but for what it is as a whole, Fallout 3 is worth your money and time no matter the price which is actually quite low now.P.S : The devs of this game totally nailed the RPG elements. The perks are fun, varied, and can lead to some major decision making outside of quests and simply on your own time.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Out of a fit of madness I uninstalled the game. then, reinstalled. On any normal game that can be modded, that would fix any issues created by mods. Instead, I only managed to break Fallout 3. I looked online and found this guide to fix Fallout 3 for Windows 7 and Windows 8.


How to Fix Fallout 3 on Windows 8 + Windows 8.1 (Only!) 
A Guide for Fallout 3
By: Nigel Burke

			A simple way to fix almost always fix Fallout 3 for Windows 8 + Windows 8.1! Now includes how to stop from random freezes and crashes happening!		


Plus, you should disable autosaves, and get CASM (a mod that auto saves every 3-5 minutes, as specified by you)http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/3729/?I tested the game for about an hour, and it worked again. albeit on a different pc, but when I first tried to launch the game it never loaded. it came a far bit and now it works fine - minus the stutters. Now to the review:I think this game is great. I have about 3-4 hundred hours in it on console, and 20 or more on pc (like I said, it crashed a lot) (also, steam says I have 3 hours, but FOSE doesn't keep track of those for steam like NVSE does for Fallout New Vegas). The quests are great. the places are great. progression is pretty good. Bethesda managed to nail the creepy, post apocolyptic atmosphere and at times you may even feel terrified. Combat is great - especially with the bloody mess perk, when all the limbs you shoot off suddenly become red pulps, and bodies explode into red mush. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I could make a joke about this game then say "10/10" at the end, but I believe this game deserves more than that.This game is absolutely incredible, anyone who says its anything less of a masterpiece is mentally handicapped.First of all, the area to explore is massive, I have over 200+ hours on it (I played a lot of it while on offline mode, so the hours on my account don't show the full amount) and I still havn't gotten around to looking over all of the areas.Second of all, the quests are amazing. Starting off with the main story, it is incredibly fun. From starting as a kid in the vault to fighting off the Enclave forces alongside a gigantic robot named Liberty Prime, it is a non-stop good time.As for the DLC's, most are equally incredible. Broken Steel, The Pitt, and Point Lookout are all amazing to say the least. While Broken Steel adds onto the main story and raises the level cap, The Pitt and Point Lookout give you entirely new quests and areas to explore, both of which are awesome. To a lesser extent, Operation Anchorage and Mothership Zeta are both somewhat decent addons, but failed to meet my expectations. Operation Anchorage was very short, I finished it in about 2 hours without rushing it, and Mothership Zeta was incredibly repetative and dont even get me started on what it attempted to do to the Lore.Alongside the Main Quests and DLC's, many of the side quests are also fantastic. One that really caught me off guard was a short little quest called "Oasis" in which after exploring the dull wasteland, you find yourself in a lush green paradise, where you meet a mutated man-turned-tree named Harold. The story is quite interesting, and depending on which ending you chose, can leave you quite upset.Now lets talk about the graphics. Yes this game is a bit outdated, but I for one think it looks fairly decent, and still hold up to some games today. As for the textures, they are quite flat, but I dont think you will really be paying attention to that while your gunning your way through hordes of Super Mutants and Ghouls.The enemies in this game are also amazing. There are plenty of enemies scattered across the Capitol Wasteland, from little pests like Radroaches and Bloatflies to the incredibly strong Deathclaws and Super Mutant Behemoths, there is little time to sit around a campfire and sing ballads about your fallen comrads before a gang of Raiders come to ruin your good time.These Raiders wont be much trouble however if your properly equiped. This game comes with a bunch of weapons which are all fun to use, such as the Combat Shotgun, the Hunting Rifle, and everyones favourite, the Fat Man. Most of these weapons also come with one or more "Unique" variations, which usually grant higher damage or special abilities, all of which are very useful when things start to get a little rough.Lastly, entertainment. I am not stretching this at all, and I dont think what Im about to say will change anytime soon. This game is the best game I have ever played. It is absolutely insane how good this game is. If I could play only 1 game for the rest of my life, it would be this. The story is great, the graphics are good, the area to explore is huge, the enemies are awesome, the replayability is off the charts, and if you ever start to get bored, a quick look over at the Nexus will keep you playing for hours on end. Now that ive said all this, I can honestly say...420/69

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I actually have more hours on this one but played it under Windows Live and much older non Steam version... but the game is so good I re-bought it on a Summer Sale. Fallout 3: Atmospheric, visually fascinating and manages to maintain your curiosity at high levels. Can't say I met any NPCs with anything resembling a personailty (with the possible exception of Moira) but that's not uncommon nowadays. Sniping with the dart gun was great fun, but the tube stations got irksome quickly. I don't see what all the fuss about VATS is - to me it just seems like cheating so I never used it. There is a lot here to interest the casual FPS and RPG fan but perhaps not enough to interest the hardcore elements of both factions. The main quest is totally uninspiring and (maybe thankfully) a fair chunk of it can be missed without warning. Plenty to see and do and I finished it 3 times which probably says more than any of the above. Definitely worth a try as *it is my most favorite game of all time!*

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I actually have more hours on this one but played it under Windows Live and much older non Steam version... but the game is so good I re-bought it on a Summer Sale. Fallout 3: Atmospheric, visually fascinating and manages to maintain your curiosity at high levels. Can't say I met any NPCs with anything resembling a personailty (with the possible exception of Moira) but that's not uncommon nowadays. Sniping with the dart gun was great fun, but the tube stations got irksome quickly. I don't see what all the fuss about VATS is - to me it just seems like cheating so I never used it. There is a lot here to interest the casual FPS and RPG fan but perhaps not enough to interest the hardcore elements of both factions. The main quest is totally uninspiring and (maybe thankfully) a fair chunk of it can be missed without warning. Plenty to see and do and I finished it 3 times which probably says more than any of the above. Definitely worth a try as *it is my most favorite game of all time!*

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Fallout 3 is a fantastic game. But, like all other games, it has its weak points. Lets start with the bad stuff. The game used to constantly freeze and forced me to end the game. It was a huge annoyance. I looked on forums to find a solution and found a simple fix in one of the games files. Thats all the bad about this game. Now for the goods! The game will take over your life. It is so addicting and theres so much to do. Every quest leaves you with choices that really make you think about what you should do. It really makes you think. The combat is really just ok. It has little variation besides vats, which is very useful ( and fun to watch the slow mo kills). Thats about all i can say bout this game. If you have the money, give it a chance, you wont regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Where do i start? First of all, Its fallout, These games are known for their action-packed, yet emotionally and path focused stories. First of all I'll adress negatives; The game is VERY dark. (this isnt a negative for all people, but for me it is, I like bright colorful scenes, with a more realistic story) Another negative is well, Later on in the story there isnt VERY much to do, although you'll find quests what bothers me is, you'll find a city with 50+ and only 1 or 2 people will give you something to do. Another thing is the ♥♥♥♥ING ACCURACY IN VATS IS AWFUL, IVE BEEN FACE FIRST WITH OVER 500 MOBS WITH A .44 REPEATER ONLY TO MISS, JESUS CHRIST. And lastly in my Cons is Optimization. some people have it worse some people have it ok, luckily i was the Ok side. The game crashes every 4 or so hours and alt-tabbing means you have to restart the entire game. Also controller support is god awful, (THE GAME HAS GWOL CAREFUL!!!)                                                                                                                                                                                                           Where do I start with the good? Jesus christ man this game, the story is godly, the dialouge options are amazing not to mention the way the ending is molded based on your choices. You'll have follows based on karma, exclusive rewards for doing good or bad deeds, it just never ends. The guns go on and on, combat is actually fun, your limbs get crippled and the game is realistic. It isnt some COD♥♥♥♥♥♥where i find ammo on every body i see, I literally need to scavenge and use my rarer rounds (.44, 308 etc) wisley and dont find them off little timmy's body. Not to mention the atmosphere (although i hate dark games) goes INCREDIBLEY WELL. The games characters and factions even put into a proper perspective what happens in such an enviorment, although ill end my review here, please, pick up this game either on a console or a PC (optimization on PC is♥♥♥♥♥♥ but play it, just play it.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												If you love a game with a post apocalyptic atmosphere, a good storyline, good graphics, and a pretty good AI, then this is the game you have been searching for.the game has a few technical issues, bugs, and not too good of player involvement, but that is common with Bethseda games, as they leave the little issues for moders to fix. Overall, the games story is pretty dark, but throughout the story, I found myself having a laugh with the characters of the game. IF you liked Skyrim, this is a game you'll want, Fallout in general is a similar version of the elder scrolls, hust a deifferent story and environment. the shooter part of the game isn't fantastic, but the story takes all the games issues and covers them with a layer of paint , and makes the paint job look very nice. this game passes with a rating of 7.9, very good.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												(Note that I have played hours of this game but steam stopped counting the play time once I press play on the launcher.) Fallout 3 is a phenomenal game and I highly recommend playing it for atleast a half hour. it's a pain to get it working on windows 7 and higher, but its worth it. If you know a lot about computers it should take around 10-15 minutes to get working but if you're a computer noob like me it should take around 30-45 minutes to get the game working with no crashes/graphical bugs.Now, lets talk about the game as a whole.Graphics yet outdated add something to it, the atmosphere of the weast land just goes with it.The AI isn't the best but it doesn't hinder the experience much.Bugs/glitches are common in the game but there more funny then anything, such as corpses spazzing out when you kill them. Some screen tearing here in there but nothing to bad, I don't think you would notice it.There is a glitch with the radio that some might have that causes the radions audio to become choppy or studder but this can be fix.Remember, this isn't like a cod game or some crap, this is a shooter that requires skill and smart thinking to get past even the most simple super mutant. This game will test you in the most epic of ways. Buy this game and be sucked into the greatest most deep game ever made. FALLOUT 4 HYPE!!!!

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												If you are looking for a cool open world RPG shooter BUY THIS GAME! This game is so amazing. Fallout 3 takes place in a post-apocalyptic Washington D.C. destroyed by nuclear war. This wasteland has been infected by horribly disgusting radiated creatures and different factions trying to control the wasteland. Fallout 3 is a very special experience. Although before you buy this game I would like to state a few of the negatives. First of all the game has not been optimized for anything newer than Windows XP so if you have Windows 7 or newer you will have to go through this process in order for the game to work. Secondly the game was made nearly 8 years ago so the graphics are kind of bad. Also the animations are clunky and the shooting can feel akward at times. But if you can get past that the game is amazing. The story feels kind of cliche but the beauty of the game. Once you leave get out into the wasteland you can completely ignore the main story and basically do whatever you want. There are interesting locations and fun quests to discover. I don't think it's as good as Skyrim but it's still an amazing RPG experience. I woud give it a 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 18
												Fallout 3 is a welcomed addition to the Fallout family, but is not without its flaws.I'll start with the positives: I thoroughly enjoyed scavenging the wastes in search of rare loot, conversing with unique characters, completing challenging quests, and going toe-to-toe with frightening creatures. Fallout 3 is brimming with content, and will surely offer you dozens of hours of enjoyment.Now for the negatives: at the time of writing, Fallout 3 is nearly nine years old, and it really shows in some areas--low resolution textures, odd facial animations, and an overall "janky" feel to many of its mechanics. The gun-play feels weak (no iron sights to be found in most weapons), the game as whole is prone to crashes, and the story ending is surprisingly underwhelming.Despite showing some age and sporting a lackluster conclusion, Fallout 3 is great fun. However, I still hold true to the notion that Fallout: New Vegas is the series' pinnacle. Regardless, Fallout 3 offers hours upon hours of entertainment, and I highly recommend picking up a copy.

												This game is great! There are tons of quests, lots of areas to explore and various weapons. The only downside there is is that you HAVE to side with the Brotherhood of Steel in the normal storyline. I recommend getting the game of the year edition; I have it for the Xbox 360 and it's way cheaper than to buy every single DLC on it's own. For the creative people among us; the G.E.C.K. is included with the game which allows you to create and edit the landscape, buildings, interiors and you can edit the stats of certain items. It's also extremely easy to create mods, so if you're new to developing this is a nice way to start.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Alright Fallout 3 is a great game, I have it on console and I love it. Wanted to take it on the go, downloaded it on steam, "Fallout 3 is not optimized for Windows 7 and later" no problem its an easy fix. My first problem: game won't launch, solution download this [http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=5549] it downloads windows live because this game is optimized for Windows Vista. You don't need to do anything with it, just install and you will have the necessary files to RUN fallout 3.My second problem: when I try to start a new game the game crashes, solution go here and download it   [https://www.dropbox.com/s/5ot8tm7szvlnuks/d3d9.dll] Once you have the file downloaded put in the Fallout 3 folder. 1. Open program files(x86)2. Steam3. Steam apps4. Common5. Fallout 3 or Fallout 3 GOTY whichever one you havePlace the d3d9.ll file in the fallout 3 folder.With that the game should be playable. If the game still crashes after trying to start a new game you can TRY this if you have a multi-cored processor. If you don't, I still recommend you try this 1. Launch the game and go to the main menu.2. While it is running, open the task manager and go to the details tab3. Right click on Fallout3.exe and go to properties4. Select compatibility and choose windows vista5. Hit APPLY THEN OK6. Right click on Fallout3.exe again and go to set affinity7. Select 1 cpu not all of them.8. Restart the game and it should workNow if the game works but you are experiencing frequent crashes you can:(WARNING THIS COULD DELETE SAVES I SUGGEST YOU GO TO Documents\My Games\Fallout3\Saves AND COPY AND PASTE ALL SAVES IN A DIFFERENT FOLDER OR ANYWHERE YOU FEEL IS EASY TO ACCESS)1. Open up the Fallout.ini file in: Documents\My Games\Fallout3 2. Find the line: bUseThreadedAI=0 (you can use ctrl+f to find it faster)3. Change it to: bUseThreadedAI=1 4. Add another line after it and insert: iNumHWThreads=2

												Fallout 3 is a breath taking game that was unreal at its time. 												This game is a masterpiece.  It took the RTS elements of the first two Fallout games, and blended them seamlessly into an fps.  Bethesda nailed it, and I'm very excited for Fallout 4. This game is on my top 10 list, and I reccomend it to any RPG/FPS fan.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												When I first ever saw Fallout 3, was when my sister was playing, and i fell in love with it. Fallout 3 is the game i must say got me into gaming in general, and its sequel "Fallout New Vegas" is what got me onto Steam in the first place, Fallout 3 technically gave me more vocabulary to use (Not the profanity) but the more advanced words, in which i knew what alot meant due to FO3 and i was using them while in 5th and 6th grade, its truly wonderful. Now i know it isnt exactly a  Rated for everyone game, but this game got my friends, not only on PSN but in school and so much more, i could have so many conversations just about this and its succeeding game, and so on. Anyways, what i loved about Fallout so much, is that it wasnt just a wasteland game, it was everything from A Nuclear Post-Apocalypse Wasteland to a Zombie Apocalypse to even a monster one. I truly do love this game, as there really is alot too do, and its plot is marvelous, and the fact that it doesnt technically make you do a quest, but gives 100+ more that you must find. Another big thing i love about it, is that it isnt modern, or technically future either, but that its staged in the 40s- 60s, and that theres always a story that backs ups your player, and then customization also. The factions are awesome too, my favorite faction actually, as one of their soldiers faces' is my profile picture, is the Enclave (Enclave Armed Forces) and that i actually would love it if one of the later Fallouts gave you the ability to really join it, and rise through the ranks, like how it was in FO3 with the Brotherhood Of Steel, and in FNV with The N.C.R and Caeser's Legion, but one can only wish and dream for right? Anyways, I totally recommend this to ALL gamers, even those who hate it because it "Sucks" in which they only say that, Because they die so quick after leaving Vault 101 and Megaton.  One miore thing, Ive replayed/played this game so much that i know how to beat it's main quest within an hour or two, and the same with all add-ons, thus is why i have Fallout3:Game Of The Year Edition on Ps3, and Regular Fallout 3 in my steam library. Love this game, it'll love you... I cannot wait for Fallout 4.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Whoa boy, radiation up the booty hole.Gameplay:Let's start with positive things, yes? The weapons do a fair amount of damage, Combat Shotgun for the win. Enemy spawn points make sense in the areas they spawn in(Which is actually important!) Most of the time the game has good spots for recovery & healing. Now the bad things, kay? The combat becomes repetitive at times. (Example, in the order it usually goes, depending on location: Raiders, Talon Company Mercs, Super Mutants/Centaurs, Mirelurks, Super Mutants.) Another thing about the Super Mutants, the Super Mutant Master can withstand two direct hits with a Missle Launcher on Normal. I know they're big, but they shouldn't be that OP.Soundtrack:Soundtrack as in the ambient tracks & atmosphere! I loved it, very dark & grimey. Makes you feel like you're absolutely trashed a long with the rest of the world, facing your actual fate. "Think Fast, Shoot Faster." is by far my favorite track during battle sequences. And the name really fits with the song itself! Great soundtrack, awesome atmosphere.Story:I like the whole idea of Trying-To-Find-Your-Father-Who-Left-Home type of story, but let's be honest. It's pretty cliché, even for a 2008 game. Didn't stop me from playing though, I liked the progression. Although the pacing of the story was extremely fast & short! I felt the story-telling had potential, but it didn't pro-long the fact that you're from a Vault, stood there for 19 years, that your dad was a top notch scientist. I felt it could have been so much longer.Visuals:Loved the disgusting visuals (That's a complement!), I've always been a sucker for destroyed cities that are covered with radiation. I noticed they went for that "Irradiated Air", effect~ Which is an absolutely sexy touch to the game! Radiation for everyone~ The default character face models are kinda meh. It seems as if the player's face is naturally low-res while the NPC faces are buffed to HD. I have found a modification for Fallout 3 to drastically increase the Player's face quality, here it is: http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/19375/?Conclusion:I could understand that the game was made by a different company, due to their different aspects of Fallout, and the fact that it was published in 2008. By all means, this game is actually not that bad. Just a few flaws here & there, but it passes the time with it's scenery & exploration! Definitely a buy.8.2/10.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												- Get Arefu Expanded Mod- Go to Arefu- Spend 3 hours f*cking around- Wait till night near a sleeping arms dealer- Steal his footlocker and safe key- Beat him to death with a cattle prod (well, unconcious.)- Throw him off the edge of Arefu - Steal all his sh*t- Start quest because he stole something from someone - Wait till next day, never see Crazy Leg Johnny in Arefu again- Think: Who needs him... I have all his sh*t and his caps! wahahahahhaha- Forget about Crazy Leg Johnny- Go do some quests in Arefu (fetch quests.. basically walking around the town for about 2 hours. Yes I did that...) - Find out Crazy Leg Johnny is trying to kill Dogmeat, your pet companion- Knock crazy leg johnny with kill command (he is apparently invincible)- Throw him off the ledge again, altho this time much farther.♥♥♥♥♥off, Johnny!- Screw around with his body while he's unconcious, and try to throw it so far it disappears- Fail miserably- Give up trying to make him disappear- Look for some random tools a guy wants you to find- Give up after 5 minutes- Go do some Moira apocalypse book quests*FAST FORWARD MUCH LATER IN THE DAY*- Feel like you need more mods- Go on Nexus, download everything that looks interesting and fun or anything that looks like "hey that could add a couple more hours of gameplay to this game."- End up adding over 300 hours worth of content with guns, armor, quests, safehouses, companions, etc- Spend hours installing 3000 mods- Spend 5 minutes sorting through mods and testing to see if game crashes- Repeat----Real ReviewI reset my entire game and now i have only around 50-100 mods. It runs way better, now. And i've only had 1 crash since.I was in the supermarket with my follower Malcom, he took out a few raiders, and I sat there behind cover firing at them. I eventually killed most of them, but then after I looted them and was in the pharmacy area, more came in. By more, I mean like 50 more. It was insane. I holed up in a room, threw a bottlecap mine, closed the door. Then I jumped over the counter and walked behind one, then he backed up into the mine, and two guys exploded. Leaving me, and Malcom.This game is amazing still even though it's so old.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Fallout 3 is an immersive, open-world RPG game. It has to be my favorite, because the storyline is compelling, and there are so many choices in the game. It strikes me as a Borderlands-type game, minus the comic humor and the overrated sexual references. Although I am a fan of first-person shooters, this game has trully earned the #1 spot on the "Most Amazing Games Ever" list. I have enjoyed the game, and I hope if any of you seek to get it that you will enjoy it as much as I did. So, get the game, play it, and hope for Fallout 4 my friends!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2011
												I love Fallout 3. Literally love it. It's so big, there's so much to do, it isn't even funny. It will take you about 100+ hours to do absolutely EVERYTHING. The graphics were a bit outdated, but they still looked good with enough detail in them. But playing in third person just felt weird. It didn't look right. But then again, the game was made to be played in first person and this is where, without a doubt, it succeeded. The VAT system is brilliant and making kills in slow motion looks kickass. The quests were awesome as well, some of them were very memorable even. I loved the quest where you first encounter the super mutant behemoth. Ah the memories... Good times ! Must own ![Rating: 92/100]
