content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Oblivion in a post apacolyptic wasteland. Pros:Huge open-world.Highly customizable character.RPG-like upgrading of your character.Wide array of weapons, armor, equipment.Pretty good main quest.Tons of side-quests for looting and XP."Schematics" which can be found, purchased, or earned for cooler weapons.Cons:Windows only; no Linux or Mac supports...yet.Online multiplayer requires a Games for Windows account (but the single player is the real meat of Fallout 3 anyway).

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Normally, I prefer to wait until I finish a game to review it, but I'd like to at least make it clear that this version of Fallout 3 is NOT stable. The game repeatedly crashed upon encountering enemies, while trying to load new music to play, or, more unpredictably, from collision detection.I had to run the game in Vista compatability mode, install an unofficial bug-fixing patch, and edit one of the game's .ini files (all in tandem) to get it to run in what I can assume is stable, so if you are that strongly determined to play Fallout 3 on PC, you have to keep in mind that you will be doing these kinds of things to the game's files, and it might not work exactly the same on your hardware. Otherwise, grab the console version of Fallout 3.It's a shame a game that's been quite good so far is brought down by its terrible instabiliy on Windows 7 and higher.==Edit for folks commenting==Seeing as a few people keep reading this as me "not reading the product description," allow me to elaborate. No, this game is not optimized for Windows 7 and later, but yes, you can make it work on a Windows 7, 8, or what have you. I knew this when I bought this. It's just a slight hassle tinkering with it and checking the program to make sure it's stable, and I don't imagine most people have the same patience for that when they could use the same time to get the console version of Fallout 3. I am willing to bet that the average person wouldn't have the same patience to do the three tasks I mentioned in order to get this running stably, thus, I am not recommending on that basis.Don't twist my words or say I'm "b---ching" when I'm not, thank you kindly.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												NOTE: I don't enjoy the Fallout series, the only one that looks playable for me is Fallout 4 and thus my opinions will be somewhat negative.    Now, Fallout was originally owned by Interplay. It was originally a top-down exploration type thing. Not even joking. Bethesda then bought the series and developed this... thing. Most gamers will say they love the Fallout series, and thus the reason Fallout 4 is doing so well in sales (plus it's a really good game). Fallout 3 is Skyrim, with guns. Just really weird gunplay mechanics sadly. The story was actually quite good, despite the fact that I don't really like this game. I can't seem to get over it all.    tl;dr Fallout 3 isn't for me, but might be for you. (hence the "yes" recommendation)

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												Great RPG. I would Actually get New Vegas.Pros:- runs smoothely(once fixed)- huge world that you can interact with your imaginations limit- Good story(voice acting, great story and lore, true to it's Sci - Fi Nature, etc)Cons:- This game should really be optimized(if not, than remastered with New Vegas at some point)Overall - 8.8/10 - An awesome RPG experience***FIX'S YOU CAN TRY***1. go into the start menu and change how the world renders with antmospheric filtering and world object rendering and launch the game(This actually worked for me, i don't know how).2. launch the game with all you settings done and press "Ctrl + Alt + Del" and go into task manager. Right click application to go to processes and look for the process that is highlighted blue. Next, right-click the highlighted process and right-click "Set Affinity." Finally, un-check all the boxes except for "CPU 1 AND CPU 0" and that's it. Go back into game, but you may have problems going back through fullscreen, so try launching in borderless windows mode.***ALL SOLOUTIONS JUST KEEP THE GAME RUNNING FOR LONGER AND DOES NOT COMPLETELY SOLVE THE PROBLEM NO MATTER WHAT TECHNIQUE YOU USE. SAVE FREQUENTLY!****EDITthere are more techniques and even apps, but try these first. They might work.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												ETA: I also play this game on Windows 10 with no problems.  I had to google how to make sure it would run - so go on and make sure you can run it on your particular version of Windows. Update: I just finished the main storyline, and...WOW.  I loved this game.  I'm disappointed, however, that you don't have the option or ability to continue playing the game after you complete the storyline.  I really wanted to be able to explore the world after beating the game.  It's really fun to be able to run all over the map and discover more places.  I wish the game had that ability (Without having to buy the DLC).I got this game on sale after hearing a lot of people talking about how much they loved it.  They warned me, said I would be gripped by it and I received numerous "RIP your social life" messages...and they were right.  This game really immerses me to the point that I lose track of time and I'm completely dead to the rest of the real world.  When I purchased this game I didn't know anything about the Fallout games other than it's a post-apocalypse after a nuclear war.  That was it.Enemies in this game range from annoying (dogs and boatflies) to creepy (feral ghouls) to monstrous (super mutant brutes...). I find that I take a lot of sadistic pleasure in wiping out entire clans of raiders, especially once they start calling me names ("only a coward hides!" yeah? eat my bullets!).  The best part about the game, however, is the level design.  The detail in Washington, DC is really impressive to me.  I've been to DC more times than I can count on both hands and I found myself recognizing places and admiring the attention to detail.  Having been in the metro hundreds of times, I also appreciated the detail in the metro stations, which was also pretty spot on.  Heck, even the sidewalks are pretty accurate.  I really appreciate the graphics.The story is intriguing and the world itself is so deep that I feel I won't be able to complete this game very quickly.  The last game that really grabbed my interest in this way was Half Life 2, which was a purchase well worth my money as well.  I definitely recommend this game to anyone regardless of your tastes in video games.  This one will change you!

Posted: May 30, 2014
												I do not recommend anyone with Windows 7 or higher to buy this game. For one reason and one reason only, it keeps on freezing and crashing with most people on the internet, and I am one of those victoms. My advise? Dont pick up this game, pick up Fallout: New Vegas. New Vegas can work for Windows 7.Dont get me wrong, Fallout 3 is a great game. But the sole fact that you cant play Fallout 3 on W7 just really disappoints me. I have look up tutorials on how to fix these issues, and I still got those problems. And the main problem is that Bethseda wont fix this, and they are currently not improving on this.If you want to play Fallout 3, just buy it for your PS3 or Xbox 360, grab the Game of the Year while your at it. Yeah, you wont play with mods, but atleast you'll still be playing the game.Edit: 12/9/2014. Recently, I modified my Fallout 3 launcher and game to be compatible for Windows 7, a simple fix. The game runs fine, but I did encountered some lag spikes from time to time, and some freezes there and here (However, I did managed to complete two quests without encountering some freezes. Only time I encountered a freeze was in my Megaton house, which happened two times. The second time happened a few seconds after starting up the game again)But man, the jump to the PC is awesome. There is a lot I can see that I couldnt see in the console ports! I do recommend this game, its pretty fun.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Think of this game as a "My First Fallout". It does a great job of introducing all the basic concepts of the series - the wasteland, vaults, factions, etc. - but is nowhere near as good as the other games in the series. Play this and then play New Vegas and you'll feel the difference. Still a fun game to play, but think of it as a stepping stone towards its superior siblingsPROS- Art style that really captures a post-apocalyptic future by way of '50s Americana- Soundtrack is amazing, featuring a mix of haunting orchestral pieces and catchy old-time swing standards- Does a (mostly) good job of transitioning from isometric turn-based combat system to first-person shooter combat- Story is more cohesive than the one in New Vegas (IMO) and gives you a good excuse for venturing out into the wasteland- Moira Brown and Three Dog are the best characters in the series. I will fight you on thisCONS- All RPG elements have been stripped to the bare minimum to the point where it's more of an action game with some RPG mechanics instead of a true RPG- Player choice is severely limited - you cannot join different groups, you can't really choose a different ending, and the final mission is little more than a corridor shooting gallery- Factions are sad parodies of their former selves- Everything that happens is triggered by your father - you are basically a spectator to his much more interesting story

Posted: November 15, 2015
												I am ready for the wave of argumentative people after they have read what I have to say. Where to start? Before I bring the negatives out, I will say how much I LIKE the game so far! I've never played Fallout 3 until this year, the story is great at the moment, the music is wonderful, I like where it is heading to and the environment is fantastic! Although I like the game, unfortunately I can't enjoy playing it. Don't get me wrong, for an old game it's expected, but the aiming is absolutely terrible. I can only get a clear shot if the person is nearly touching me. My other downfall is the unexpected freezing of the game, at least seven to eight times it has occurred today leaving me frustrated and heavy.I wish I could recommend this game, but I just can't due to the issues on my part.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												A classic of modern gaming and a game everyone had already played or at least heard about.In the year 2077, the Earth was destroyed by a nuclear war. A company called Vault-Tec started building giant underground shelters several years prior to the war, so that, in case something happens, people can continue living in those safe places. Now, 200 years after the war, you play a young character whose father suddenly left the vault and caused a state of panic in the vault and you decide to leave after him. You open the vault door and step outside into an utterly destroyed and dangerous world, following clues to find your father and find what he's been up to.The world is open, you can go wherever you want from the beginning, and it's filled with a lot of side quests, locations to explore, enemies to kill and corpses to loot.Compared to the previous two Fallout games, this one is a bit different. Not only the game is fully 3D, but it's also set on the east coast, as opposed to the west like before, where everything seems to be much more affected by the bombs and people haven't been able to establish reliable sources of food, water, or even settlements, so most of them live inside creatively built places inside ruins of already existing world objects, while being constantly in danger of raiders, bandits, mutants, and other enemies who are fighting to get food and supplies.Pros:+Open world+Fun and engaging combat system+The world is full of interesting places to explore+There is a crafting system+Some quests are pretty unique and entertainingCons:-Dialogs are kinda binary and shallow.-Some of the "big" choices don't seem to matter because no one acknowledges them (*cough* Megaton *cough*)-Levelling system has less depth than in the previous games, and perks aren't that useful since most of them just add points to your skills.-Writing in the game is boring and the story is predictable.Overall, it's definitely a fun game, despite it's flaws. Fallout may have changed, but war, war never changes.

												1) go to PC> [Whatever drive FO3 is on]>  Program Files (x86)>  Steam> Steamapps> Common> Fallout 32) Right click on Fallout3 file and pick "Properties"3) Go to "Compatibility" in the properties menu4) Check the box that says, "Run this program in compatibility for:"5) Under that, click the box and choose, "Windows Vista"6) Press "ok"7) Enjoy!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Fallout 3's plot summary.Dad killed himself rather than let his broken machine fall into the hands of people trying to fix it. As a result, a water purifier that has no reason to exist released radiation it shouldn't have, thus killing Col Autumn, who had no reason to be there. Later we got through a villiage of children who fdso gah frrzlmpr blaa huygnnl asdf so we could enter vault 87 and recover a GECK, a device which would be better put to use in virtually any possible manner besides the one for which we had aquired it. Then Col Autumn, who shouldn't be alive, but is, captured us with a flash grenade that shouldn't have worked in a place he shouldn't have been able to reach, so he could stop us from fixing the machine he wanted fixed. He then tortured us for a code that didn't matter which we had no reason not to give him. Then, the president, which is a computer for absolutely no reason, set us free to enact his plan which was of benefit to absolutely no one, and then kills himself for no reason whatsoever.At the final battle, everyone in the world has the same goal: Turn on the water purifier. Due to this overwhelming consensus, we were obliged to fight a massive war. Finally, Col Autumn gave his life to stop us from turning on the machine he was trying to turn on. At the end, the Enclave defeated themselves by sabotaging the machine they where trying to activate, causing it to explode even though it shouldn't, and obliging us to enter the purifier and die of radiation that wasn't actually lethal. At least until the DLC retconned our death, making everything Fawkes ever said to you a lie. A ghoul companion refused to enter the chamber, even though ghouls are healed by radiation.It's a fun game otherwise.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Once again Bethesda has really shown us what they're capable of Fallout 3 has a fantastic gameplay and the open world is highly detailed and fun to explore, although the story is not as interesting or strong as the previous Fallout games. Fallout is a third and first person RPG open world game that is set in a post-apocalyptic retro-future world. Fallout 3 takes place in the year 2277, 36 years after the setting of Fallout 2 and 200 years after the nuclear apocalypse that devastated the game's world in a future where international conflicts between the United States and China culminated in a Sino-American war in 2077. In Fallout 3 your decisions always have an effect on the story, for example if you choose to kill this person or let this person live the ending will be different depending on the decisions you make and the people you kill will never respawn so you must make a good choice as each decision has a consequence. After you have finished the main storyline there is many other things to do from a range of different side-missions to exploring the openworld. Overall I give this game a 8/10 the story is not as powerful as the previous Fallout games as everything else is fantastic the story is what needs working on. Still despite having a weak and boring story I still think FO3 is fantastic in terms of openworld and gameplay. If you don't really care too much about the weak and horrible story and you are only getting it for the open world and gameplay features then I suggest you go and get this epic game I am absolutely sure it will blow you away without a doubt!.

number of helpful: 33 of 67 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												Fallout 3 is an extremely deceptively named game. Looking at the title you might expect to find a game that has something in common with the previous Fallout games yet what is actually hidden inside Fallout 3 is not a Fallout game, it is an Oblivion re-skin.Everything is pretty much the same as in Oblivion except it is now even more dated than before, the graphics, the path-finding AI, the inventory system, every piece of tech is horrible outdated and would feel out of place in an indie title.Fallout 3 tries to incorporate some of the features that made the old Fallout games eternal classic but it does so in the same low budget way it does everything else. Skill based dialog is in, but the writing is so atrocious that you actually feel slightly stupider for selecting it. All the names and items are in, Vaults, Nuka-Cola, Super Mutants, etc etc. But Bethesda never bothered to find out anything about them beyond the name, nothing has the same meaning in Fallout 3 that it did in Fallout 1 & 2. Instead Bethesda went for the quick-fix, the instant gratification.The game is even built for reviewers. As you leave the Vault for the first time you will find a ton of people, places and quests in your immediate vicinity and the first 3-4 hours of gameplay is highly content packed. But once you go beyond that starting area things quickly becomes more sparse and it's not uncommon to find a town consisting of 2 quest-givers and a merchant.Fallout 3 is not a Fallout game. It's Oblivion with Super Mutants and Nuka-Colas. Nothing more, nothing less.Buy this if you liked Oblivion but thought it would have been more entertaining with guns. Don't buy this if you expect a Fallout game.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2013
												While the game starts out with excellent premise, the game as a whole I found rather boring, the combat is not entertaining, the main campaign is incredibly dull and there was no incentive to do sidequests. Getting anywhere takes forever and it's not that pretty a game so it can't really distract you, and everything is just grey. No matter where you are it's just grey, I understand that it's a post apocalyptic setting but there was no substance to it.On a lighter note the voice acting was excellent, there was some entertaining levels such as the one in the "perfect world" where you are a child who murders everyone, and the different ways to play also changed up the game a bit. But other than those notes I could just not find it entertaining at all.I know it gets rave reviews everywhere but I just could not enjoy whether it was overhyped I'm not sure but it was boring to me.

content:
Posted: April 11
												To make a lasagna u need : For the tomato meat sauce:2 x 28 oz. cans tomatoes - crushed or whole is best! If you get whole canned tomatoes just crush them in your hands.1-2 tbsp tomato paste (this is my favorite kind!)1 large oniongarlic, garlic, garlic - I always use a ton! I'd say two cloves minimum!1 pound ground beef, preferably lean1 pound Italian sausage - choose whatever spice level you like!dried oreganoItalian seasoningsalt and pepperfresh basil - dried can also be substituted!olive oilKeep in mind that if you can always just cook up some meat and then pour a couple jars of tomato sauce over it, so don't worry about it if you look at the ingredients and wonder what you've gotten yourself into.For the rest of the lasagna:1 package of noodles (should be around a pound in weight) - oven-ready or regular.1 lb. mozzarella1/2 lb. good quality parmesan1 lb. ricotta cheese1 eggdried oregano + basilHardware:large pan to make the sauce in13x9 baking dish - I recommend glasslarge pot for boiling pasta (if not using oven-ready noodles)]Step 2: Making the Meat Sauce, Part OnePrep work and browning the meat!Roughly dice the onion, and mince as much garlic as you want. I used quite a bit as you can see. :DOnce you've got the veggies prepped, film your sauce pan with olive oil. Heat the pan over medium and cook the ground beef and Italian sausage until browned. If a lot of fat seeps out, drain most of it. You need only a few tablespoons of fat to cook the onion and garlic in.Once you've drained the extra fat, throw in the onions and garlic.Stir this around for a few minutes over medium heat until the onions become soft. Then add in a few good pinches of Italian seasoning, a pinch of basil, oregano and salt, and a tablespoon or two of tomato paste.Step 3: Making the Meat Sauce, Part TwoNow, open both cans of tomatoes and dump them in. Mix it around for a moment, and bring to a light boil. Watch out for splatters!Lower the heat to a simmer and cover. Let the sauce simmer for at least a half hour while you do the rest of the prep work.Step 4: Cook (or Don't Cook) Your NoodlesAt this point, if you're using regular lasagna noodles, you'll need to fill a stock pot with water and cook those. I find it's best to cook them for the shortest time listed on the package or a minute or two under so they don't get soggy while the lasagna bakes.Once they're done, rinse them with cold water using a colander and set them aside. Try to separate them a bit so they stick less later.If you're using oven-ready noodles, you can worry about them later. :DStep 5: Prep the Cheese and Finish the SauceOver the years, I've started combining all my cheese at the beginning - it makes for easier assembly!Grab out a couple handfuls of parmesan and mozzarella and put them in a small bowl - this will be for topping the lasagna.Place the ricotta into a large bowl, along with one egg. Add the rest of the parmesan and mozzarella, as well as a couple good pinches of Italian seasoning and basil. Mix this all together with your hands.Once you're all done with the cheese, double check the sauce and adjust the flavors as necessary. You may need to add salt, sugar or more herbs - just keep adding and testing until it's good for you!If you're using fresh basil, chop up a handful and throw it in now. Once the basil is in, stir the sauce well and turn off the heat.Step 6: Assembling!Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F / 200 degrees C.Make sure your cheeses, noodles and sauce are all within easy reach.Ladle just enough sauce to cover the bottom of the pan. Then place noodles on top of the sauce just to cover, slightly overlapping. (If you're using over-ready noodles, follow the box directions) If they're broken, piece them together as much as possible. Spread 1/3 of the cheese mixture over the noodles.Now you'll put more sauce over the cheese and then noodles, more cheese, and then sauce again. You repeat the basic build three times.For the fourth and final level, lay down your cheese mixture and top with the rest of the sauce. Now sprinkle the parmesan and mozzarella you set aside over it.Now bake at 375 F for 40 minutes - if you're using a metal pan, check after 30 and make sure it's not too dark! If it's starting to get dark on top just pull it out. :)Once it's done baking, pull it out and let it sit for a few minutes before cutting into it! Otherwise it will just be hot lasagna lava.Serve it to a bunch of hungry friends and/or family with warm garlic bread and enjoy your hero status. :D

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Windows 7 came out in 2009. The internal differences between that and vista were negligible, but apparently this game is such a hack that it has issues and Bethesda could not even be arsed to fix them within a year of the game's release (despite making content pack after content pack).But that really should be par for the course for the most incompetent developers in PC gaming history. My personal favorite moron moment was the randomly-generated starting dungeon in Daggerfall that was impossible to complete because it didn't randomly generate an exit. At least that game had some redeeming qualities. Fallout 3 does not.It doesn't make a damn bit of sense if you compare it to the other Fallouts, but the game is crap just on its own merits. Like every Bethesda game, the world is pointless and sterile and the quests are poorly written. The fact that it's set in the Fallout world just slaps insult on top of injury.What kind of idiots design an entire town full of annoying as♥♥♥♥♥♥children in a game where you are specifically not allowed to kill children? In a series notable for being able to do things like murder children and become a slaver? This thing is just an embarrassment. Thank goodness I have the old Fallouts from GoG.com before Bethesda acted like whiney babies and removed their games from any DRM-free service. Of course they want to control your access to better games from the past: They can only make their design seem like the incompetent♥♥♥♥♥♥show that it is.0 stars out of five. The fact that it will literally not run on a modern OS is its only redeeming quality. Oh yeah, and the fact that the game's heavy-handed (and obviously poorly written) story kills you at the very game. You won't be tempted to play this turd any more than you have to, provided you are on some kind of ancient, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ operating system needed to play it.Steam gets an additional 0 stars out of five for continuing to sell a game that  will not work on their service. No, a "not optimized for" minimum (lack of) responsibility warning is not sufficient. The game *WILL NOT RUN* on windows 8. I don't care what Gabe Newell's burrito-stuffing fat♥♥♥♥♥says about Windows 8; it is fast and very stable. It is unconscionable to continue to sell software that a modern OS cannot run.

												Okay, so I finally finished Fallout 3. number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Fallout 3 is... something. I can't really put into words why I don't like it. The graphics are fine by me (somehow), the quests are vibrant and unique, the characters are each of their own, but it just didn't work for me. I thought about if for an hour, after which I figured it out: Fallout 3 is TINY. Now sure, it doesn't look it, but it is. The game map is a tenth the size of Skyrim's, and if it's actually bigger it stil felt small. There are so many locations that the wasteland has the population density of NYC, and it takes about 5 hours from finding an area to figuring out what quest it's used for. There's a quest involving vampires and it took me an hour to find the correct area as their hideout alone, becauase I had a 45 degree area to search and there were 4 locations that fit the bill immediately out the gate. The quests are miniscule in number as well. Once you've completed the story, you've seen half of the major quests and the game doesn't let you keep playing after the main questline is over. God knows why. Every quest that isn't part of the main story is a one-off, no metter how clever. The skill system reflects the rest of the game, in that it is deceptive, and perpetually smaller than it looks. With the right SPECIAL point allocation you can see half of the perks from the very beginning. There is also a wide variety of weapons, but at level 70 you'll be looking at the same guns as at level 1 so that you've seen every gun 1000 times and by that point you've realized how static the gun variety is. In Skyrim, you started the game with 7 weapons and end with over 100, but in Fallout 3 you start with 30 and end with 35. I'm pretty sure that the Enclave has some weapons that aren't unlocked straight out the gate but with some fiddling you can pick those up in hour 6. The majority of the game is in random encounters that are over in a flash.Many of the coolest characters and factions are woefully underdeveloped. The Brotherhood and Enclave don't do jack until the story's endgame, with most others just sitting on their♥♥♥♥♥until their quest begins. Then they stop mattering once their quest is over. A major set of different armors isn't usable until your 2/3rds through the game. The most powerful weapon in the game can be found at any time, and you'll never know if I'm referring to the ray-gun or mini-nuke launcher because they are both instantly available. Skill point allocation is entirely manual, so the bare-knuckle mass murderer can totally put all of his training time and fighting experience into learning laser guns. It doesn't even matter, because the gunplay is just awful. You're expected to use a statistic-based aim-assist instead of the sights, so unless you put points into whatever SPECIAL that ups your VATS-points (they're really poorly defined) you basically can't fight anything.There's a wide variety of different sub-games at play at any given moment, from damage checks to weapon condition to hacking skill (if that's what you're currently doing) but none of them matter beyond a few examples. Every weapon class has one or two weapons which are better than all the others, so once you get enough points into whatever to get it, don't bother.Really, the game is just empty and overfull at the same time. I wouldn't recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												To note, I know my account says only like  120 minutes but it's because I had to mod it to get it to work.Overal I give the game a 6 out of 10 and here is why.Graphics:The graphics of Fallout 3 are pretty good. The world looks very bleak, desolate and  quite lovely for the theme of Fallout. The problem I have is the random hitching and tearing of  parts of  buildings. Perhaps it was because of my settings not fallout. The other thing I noticed a lot was most of the faces of the normal humans were ugly. Just plain ole ugly, like obvilion ugly.Story:The  story  is awful. SPOILERS DO NOT READ THIS IF YOU WANT TO PLAY THE GAME.I don't get how the begining and ending  is even good. I don't see how any reasonable person would be like,♥♥♥♥♥♥YOUR FATHER  LEFT? WELL WE ARE GOING TO TRY TO KILL  YOU  BECAUSE OF HIM AND HOW JONAS DIED!!!And when are we going to stop doing the  whole, sacrifice yourself for  the greater good? Almost every game out there has that. Either you destroy everoyne with that virus in the water, you don't  fix the purifier or  you sacrifice yourself for the greater good. I love how there was only 39 rads per second, you could easily buff/rad x  out that but wait, it's a cut scene so yeah. The side quests/changed in the world are rather enjoyable. Such as getting the ghouls into tenpenny tower and many other aspects that I found enjoyable.Leveling system/RPG aspect:The leveling system stays true to Fallout series. You start by making out your character like normal,  as you level you get skill points, get to tag skills and etc. The perks are enjoyable but a lot  of the perks/skills are useless..  I mean you absoultely don't even need bartering skills because caps are almost worthless because you can trade everything for everything. I basically had about 200+ stims  near  early game which means I basically could not die. I do like how the speech skill was worth while to get certain things done anther way.Bugs:This game had an awful a lot of bugs with certain NPCs getting stuck, randomly dying and etc. Not to mention I had to mod the hell out of this game for a steam game and for Windows 7. I know the game is a bit dated but I never ever had to change much for other games that are the same age.Regardless, I suggest getting a few of the game fixing mods.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												This game has NOT aged well; here are the reasons:1. Takes around 1-2 hours to sort out the bugs (including: crashing at start, minimizing at random intervals, crashing when entering rooms, lagging when someone speaks, freezing)2. Downloading the programs and unofficial patches to fix said bugs3. The game was left to rot by bethesda for they are now too busy making DLC for fallout 44. There's a part in the game where you have to battle a lot of mutants (I mean a LOT; mini gunners, hunters and even mutants with smg's) and I thought, well I'm too new to the game so I might as well stick it on very easy... NOPE nothing changed, literally nothing, I restarted the game and restarted my PC, nothing. Sqwat. It took me about 2 hours to get the game working, plus another 1 hour because the bugs came back and then. I got♥♥♥♥♥♥on.5. Because it uses a installer when you start it, it closes itself to open the game. So basically steam won't track how long you've played for. As I'm writing this, I'll have to copy and paste it back because I only have 8 minutes on it. I'm literally going to have to waste 20 minutes of my life just on the installer, because if I hit play I'll have to restart it.Ok now for the Pros1. VATS is to DIE for, I love it to bits and I can't wait to see it in other games, obviously renamed.2. The plot to it is amazing as well as the story.3. The graphics are brilliant for its time.4. Fast travel is brilliant, much better than having to walk back through metro station.5. The multiple choice is great, I had the choice to either blow up a nuke or disarm it.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												This game has NOT aged well; here are the reasons:1. Takes around 1-2 hours to sort out the bugs (including: crashing at start, minimizing at random intervals, crashing when entering rooms, lagging when someone speaks, freezing)2. Downloading the programs and unofficial patches to fix said bugs3. The game was left to rot by bethesda for they are now too busy making DLC for fallout 44. There's a part in the game where you have to battle a lot of mutants (I mean a LOT; mini gunners, hunters and even mutants with smg's) and I thought, well I'm too new to the game so I might as well stick it on very easy... NOPE nothing changed, literally nothing, I restarted the game and restarted my PC, nothing. Sqwat. It took me about 2 hours to get the game working, plus another 1 hour because the bugs came back and then. I got♥♥♥♥♥♥on.5. Because it uses a installer when you start it, it closes itself to open the game. So basically steam won't track how long you've played for. As I'm writing this, I'll have to copy and paste it back because I only have 8 minutes on it. I'm literally going to have to waste 20 minutes of my life just on the installer, because if I hit play I'll have to restart it.Ok now for the Pros1. VATS is to DIE for, I love it to bits and I can't wait to see it in other games, obviously renamed.2. The plot to it is amazing as well as the story.3. The graphics are brilliant for its time.4. Fast travel is brilliant, much better than having to walk back through metro station.5. The multiple choice is great, I had the choice to either blow up a nuke or disarm it.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Unfortantly this game is completly unplayable as it is. If you plan on playing for more than 10min without it crashing without using mods or going into the games coding and changing stuff. When the crashing occurs: When you first get out the vault, when you open the door to Megaton, and opening random doors that the game has to load the next area. Yes my pc can run this game. I5-3000 series, 4gb of ram, and a 650 ti boost. If youre getting this game and plan to mod it then i recommend it but if youre worried about modding or changing the games coding then dont bother with this game. It's pretty sad that this game has been out for so long and Bethesda hasn't patched their broken game.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Fallout 3 takes place in the year 2277, 116 years after the setting of Fallout, 36 years after the setting of Fallout 2 and 200 years after the nuclear apocalypse that devastated the game's world, in a future where international conflicts between the United States and China culminated in a Sino-American war in 2077, due to the scarcity of petroleum reserves that ran the economies of both countries. The player character is an inhabitant of Vault 101, a survival shelter designed to protect up to 1,000 humans from the nuclear fallout. When the player character's father disappears under mysterious circumstances, the leader of the Vault initiates martial law and sends security forces after the player, who is forced to escape from the Vault and journey into the ruins of Washington, D.C. to track their father down. Along the way the player is assisted by a number of human survivors and must battle a myriad of enemies that inhabit the area, now known as the "Capital Wasteland". Fallout 3 is my all time favorite game I love it. fallout 3 pros are   cool looking guns fun gunplay. cool looking armor fun sidequests cons laggy at spots  main quest is too short not that many side quests  bad gunplay. Overall this is my opinion of fallout 3 9/10

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												I wanted to be a good guy... ended up killing 600 people or more.5/10 will possibly be the Last, Best Hope of Humanity again just for the sake of bloodshed in the name of peace.In a serious note... I recommend the game because is fun... but in terms of story (shallow) or combat (annoying) or NPCs (NO POSSIBLE CARE) the whole experience is kind of absurd. There is no free will in this open vast world. You kill every bad guy or hostile and you become automatically a good guy... or you can be an serial killer of good people. In the end does not matter... trust me.  Unless you like slideshows.Do not level yourself up before the main quests: the game tends to be easy and the AI of your "non essential" allies became bug-liability kind of experience.But it is fun to watch everyone exploding in blood and guts in slow-mo VATS action, it reminds me of how non-sensical this existence in...  as it was  President Eden and the Enclave over the top hostility, because PLOT .

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												>Played New Vegas first>Didn't really enjoy it cuz of boring intro>Then get this game while On Sale>Play it  >The game has better intro than New Vegas                     >Spend most of my life in the Wasteland than in Real LifeSummary:+ Better Intro than NV, so new players can learn the Lore better+ Multi-solution, you can finish quest the way you like+ You make your own character, also what make them SPECIAL+ Unlike other RPG, you can still use weapons even if your weapon skill is low+ Karma System, one of gameplay mechanic that shouldn't removed from Fallout 4+ V.A.T.S.+ Bloody Mess perk!!            - Bugs. Yeah, every Bethesda games have bugs- 2nd most linear Fallout games- You can be evil in this game, but you can't join the Enclave (an evil corporation)- To fully enjoy the game, you need to get GOTY or at least, get the Broken Steel DLCIs it worth it? => Yes, but for some of you maybe No                               Recomended for: Those who are new to Fallout series, those who can't handle Fallout 4 but still want to play, Those who like Post-Apocalypse, First/Third Person RPG, those who want freedom on doing anythingNot Recomended for: Those who expect Turn-Based Fallout (if you do, get Wasteland instead), those who scared by mutant, ghoul, etc, for those who want Non-Linear RPGWell, Fallout 3 is a good game, just don't compare them to other Fallout games. Also, if you've finished playing this, I recommend getting Fallout: New Vegas next. Don't forget to check my New Vegas review!! xD

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												After trying to play this game through several times, I always ended up getting bored because this game was just wasn't enough fun, it was boring. But then, Fallout 4 came out and after playing that through and exploring the world, the new world I thought why not give another try to Fallout 3 and see if it gets me after playing FO4. It did, for some reason I felt like I knew most of the things, I experienced a newer version of the similar systems in Fallout 4 and Fallout 3 didn't seem like an old weird boring game anymore. Of course after playing through Fallout 4 and 3 I realised that 4 is a much better game and it is more suitable for new Fallout players like myself. Now I don't want to say that Fallout 3 is a bad game because it isn't, it is a very fun game.....was a very fun game. Perhaps if I had played Fallout 3 when it came out I would have liked it and I would be a fan of the series, but right now I have to say that I am a fan of Fallout 4, not fallout 3. What I'm trying to say is that if you have never played a fallout game before because you weren't interested or you have played and thought it was boring than perhaps you shouldn't start here, go buy Fallout 4, and if you like it then give this a try.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												This game is one of my favorites of all time, and if you have money left from pre-ordering Fallout 4 (assuming you did so) then I would definitely recommend getting the GOTY edition (I was stupid enough to accidentally buy this, save some money and get the GOTY version) and play it until it comes out. Even with Fallout 4, however, consider this about the game:PROS:-Amazing atmosphere. In post-apocalyptic Washington D.C, you feel the fight for survival at ALL times-Entertaining side-quests that can literally suck you in-Most of the entire game is a pro.CONS:-Woot! Gunna use my Fat Man- ♥♥♥♥ THE GAME CRASHED! (seriously, this will crash crash crash and will do so until you install around 5 different mods for it)-WEAK main quest. I finished the main quest in about 4 hours and felt empty. Thankfully the numerous side-quests and DLC quests will keep you occupied for weeks on end.-Without mods the mechanics (especially fine-aiming) feel incredibly awkward, mainly in comparison to New Vegas. However, that game has its own set of flaws too.-Nothing else, other than the Gamebryo engine itself looking like complete @$$ for the majority of the game. Seriously, install the Fellout mod as well as some textures/subtle ENB effects (don't oversaturate it!). Then the game will look greatOverall a must-play for any RPG fan.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Vault-Tec engineers have worked around the clock on an interactive reproduction of Wasteland life for you to enjoy from the comfort of your own vault. Included is an expansive world, unique combat, shockingly realistic visuals, tons of player choice, and an incredible cast of dynamic characters. Every minute is a fight for survival against the terrors of the outside world — radiation, Super Mutants, and hostile mutated creatures. From Vault-Tec, America's First Choice in Post Nuclear Simulation. Limitless Freedom! Take in the sights and sounds of the vast Capital Wasteland! See the great monuments of the United States lying in post-apocalyptic ruin! You make the choices that define you and change the world. Just keep an eye on your Rad Meter! Experience S.P.E.C.I.A.L.! Vault-Tec engineers bring you the latest in human ability simulation — the SPECIAL Character System! Utilizing new breakthroughs in points-based ability representation, SPECIAL affords unlimited customization of your character. Also included are dozens of unique skills and perks to choose from, each with a dazzling variety of effects! Fantastic New Views! The wizards at Vault-Tec have done it again! No longer constrained to just one view, experience the world from 1st or 3rd person perspective. Customize your view with the touch of a button! The Power of Choice! Feeling like a dastardly villain today, or a Good Samaritan? Pick a side or walk the line, as every situation can be dealt with in many different ways. Talk out your problems in a civilized fashion, or just flash your Plasma Rifle. Blast 'Em Away With V.A.T.S.! Even the odds in combat with the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System for your Pip-Boy Model 3000! V.A.T.S. allows you to pause time in combat, target specific body parts on your target, queue up attacks, and let Vault-Tec take out your aggression for you. Rain death and destruction in an all-new cinematic presentation. Mind-Blowing Artificial Intelligence! At Vault-Tec, we realize that the key to reviving civilization after a global nuclear war is people. Our best minds pooled their efforts to produce an advanced version of Radiant AI, America's First Choice in Human Interaction Simulation. Facial expressions, gestures, unique dialog, and lifelike behavior are brought together with stunning results by the latest in Vault-Tec technology. Eye-Popping Prettiness!*: Witness the harsh realities of nuclear fallout rendered like never before in modern super-deluxe HD graphics. From the barren Wasteland, to the danger-filled offices and metro tunnels of DC, to the hideous rotten flesh of a mutant's face.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Riding off the heels of The Elder Scrolls IV, Bethesda had purchased the rights to the Fallout name. Fallout 3 is a welcoming break from the bright fantasy world that The Elder Scrolls has so familarized us with. The gameplay is very good albeit not perfect, ironsights are implemented only with mods, using the V.A.T.S system is pretty cool for a while but after using it for a while it starts to get boring just seeing bodies explode into ooey-gooey bits. There are a variety of weapons ranging from pistols to rifles and even an electrically powered slegde hammer. There are also many disgusting creatures to come across in this post-apocolyptic world. The visuals have not aged very well but (yet again) with the help of mods you can create a visually stunning experience. The story is okay at best and pretty generic at worst, but that doesn't go without saying how immersed this game makes you feel with it's large scale and barren yet rich enviroment. Overall, this is a fantastic game and deserves the previous praise, I give it a very confident 8.5/10.

Perhaps if I had played Fallout 3 when it came out I would have liked it and I would be a fan of the series, but right now I have to say that I am a fan of Fallout 4, not fallout 3. What I'm trying to say is that if you have never played a fallout game before because you weren't interested or you have played and thought it was boring than perhaps you shouldn't start here, go buy Fallout 4, and if you like it then give this a try.

Posted: May 24, 2015
												I heard about this game for years, but never got it until May 22, 2015, but didn't start playing until May 23rd, 2015. I didn't own a PlayStation 3 or Xbox 360, which explains why I never played this game until May 23rd, 2015. Now, why is that day important? It's important because that's the day I played the best game ever in my opinion. The game is basically a Post-Apocalyptic, Post-Nuclear RPG FPS, which sounds amazing, and luckily, that is the case with Fallout 3. Most times with games, the first game in the series is the best and any others are usually inferior. However, Not with Fallout 3. While Fallout and Fallout 2 are basically masterpieces, Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel was okay, Fallout: Brotherhood of Steel was awful, having mixed reactions with many critics. While Fallout 2 offered a more variety of things and Fallout: Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel was the first and only (On PC at least) Fallout to have multiplayer, Fallout: Brotherhood of Steel wasn't good and should of never existed. Go to the year 2004, where Bethesda owns the entire Fallout franchise. A teaser is shown in 2007 for the game known as  Fallout 3. 1 year later, Bethesda releases Fallout 3. The game is given high reviews, named best RPG, best PC game, best Xbox 360 game, and of course, THE BEST GAME OF THE YEAR.Fallout 3 is amazing and I highly recommend it to anybody who likes the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series or any of the other Fallout games, you won't be disappointed. Sadly, this game is given a 85% on Steam because Bethesda won't fix it and people are too lazy to look up how to fix it. I fixed it almost instantly, with the only thing I had to download was GFWL, and luckily, it isn't bad here. Otherwise, it's just tweaking things in the Fallout 3 files. It runs great on my Alienware 15 and I'm happy I got this. However, I would recommend getting "Fallout 3: Game of the Year Edition" because you get all of the DLC, and if you were to buy all the DLC seperate, it would cost more than the actual GOTY edition (GOTY: $19.99; All DLC combined: $24.95) Please, get this game.EDIT: I beat the game in 6 days and it took 25 hours (5 Hours and 45 minutes offline) to beat. IT IS the best RPG I have ever played in my life. You have to get this game, you'll love it.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												(Warning: This is long)First off, you may be considering to buy Fallout 3 due to Fallout 4 almost being fully released. But if you actually want Fallout 3 for a different reason, like the nostalgic feel, or just because why not. In this review I will be discussing many topics, so grab your pencils and start writing!STORY The story line in Fallout 3, may not be the most interesting, but it is deffinetly worth the time. Now on the other hand, side-quests are another thing that come to play in Fallout 3. Side-quests, some fun, some creepy, and some even borning, are EVERYWHERE. To anyone who can do every single side-quest in the game without getting bored, or just go insain, I salute you. Story rating: 4.7/5GAMEPLAYGameplay is... well, gameplay. There is not much to say about the gameplay of Fallout besdies, it's good. Let's look at this in a broken-down fashion. Weapons are a big part of Fallout, they are what get you through the entire game, you can not go without any sort of weapon. How many weapons are there, you may be asking. Well, let's just say... over 110. Armor and Clothing is another part of Fallout, wearing armor will incrase the ammount of damage resistance you have, some armor peices even add special stats (such as +5 int). There are also junk items, and some other items, but it would take too long to list them all. Gameplay rating: 5/5AUDIOFallout has very good audio. That is, if you can hear it all. Some audio in Fallout is not able to be heard, unless you either have a decent headset, in the perfect area, or by Radio signals. There are mods which can even add better audio quality to the game. Audio rating: 4.6/5GLITCHESAh, Bethesda... what Bethesda game can you have without glitches? There are your regular minor texture or sound glitches, but usually nothing too serious. There are, or atleast was, gamebreaking glitches. These glitches can ruin your game in a good, and funny way, or in a more.. bad way. There are mods that fix most of these though.(Additional) Running Fallout 3 on a system that has Windows 7 or later.Fallout was never ment for Windows 7 or any later versions, so if you do own Windows 7, or any later version, you will probably have to dig through the files of the game, and download some mods so the game will run properly.FINAL RATING: 4.9/5

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												This game is one of my favorites of all time, and if you have money left from pre-ordering Fallout 4 (assuming you did so) then I would definitely recommend getting the GOTY edition (I was stupid enough to accidentally buy this, save some money and get the GOTY version) and play it until it comes out. Even with Fallout 4, however, consider this about the game:PROS:-Amazing atmosphere. In post-apocalyptic Washington D.C, you feel the fight for survival at ALL times-Entertaining side-quests that can literally suck you in-Most of the entire game is a pro.CONS:-Woot! Gunna use my Fat Man- ♥♥♥♥ THE GAME CRASHED! (seriously, this will crash crash crash and will do so until you install around 5 different mods for it)-WEAK main quest. I finished the main quest in about 4 hours and felt empty. Thankfully the numerous side-quests and DLC quests will keep you occupied for weeks on end.-Without mods the mechanics (especially fine-aiming) feel incredibly awkward, mainly in comparison to New Vegas. However, that game has its own set of flaws too.-Nothing else, other than the Gamebryo engine itself looking like complete @$$ for the majority of the game. Seriously, install the Fellout mod as well as some textures/subtle ENB effects (don't oversaturate it!). Then the game will look greatOverall a must-play for any RPG fan.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												This is a game where your main goal is to click a button on a menu that says  "New Game" and then the game ends.  I thought that this game ended in a very odd way, however, I found out quickly that through some computer wizardry it was possible to acesses a  SECRET BONUS PLOTLINE  that was included in the game, where you played as a small child trying to learn to walk. Once you take the first step the game then ends again, bringing you to the desktop like before. Through more forementioned wizardry (See Bonus Plotline  above) I found yet another story about growing up in a vault under the ground and eventually attempting to leave said vault. Once you leave the vault the game asks if you want to switch genders and then ends. I felt that the game was a little overpriced for its legnth and overall quality, but I do think that the game needs to be appreciated for the message it's trying to convey, by showing the player that life is nothing but a series of goals, and it never truly ends with one big event, but with collections of smaller events that make up our lives, and I think the game needs to be appreciated for that.4/10 buy the XBox version or learn how to mod the Havok engine.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Vault-Tec engineers have worked around the clock on an interactive reproduction of Wasteland life for you to enjoy from the comfort of your own vault. Included is an expansive world, unique combat, shockingly realistic visuals, tons of player choice, and an incredible cast of dynamic characters. Every minute is a fight for survival against the terrors of the outside world — radiation, Super Mutants, and hostile mutated creatures. From Vault-Tec, America's First Choice in Post Nuclear Simulation. Limitless Freedom! Take in the sights and sounds of the vast Capital Wasteland! See the great monuments of the United States lying in post-apocalyptic ruin! You make the choices that define you and change the world. Just keep an eye on your Rad Meter! Experience S.P.E.C.I.A.L.! Vault-Tec engineers bring you the latest in human ability simulation — the SPECIAL Character System! Utilizing new breakthroughs in points-based ability representation, SPECIAL affords unlimited customization of your character. Also included are dozens of unique skills and perks to choose from, each with a dazzling variety of effects! Fantastic New Views! The wizards at Vault-Tec have done it again! No longer constrained to just one view, experience the world from 1st or 3rd person perspective. Customize your view with the touch of a button! The Power of Choice! Feeling like a dastardly villain today, or a Good Samaritan? Pick a side or walk the line, as every situation can be dealt with in many different ways. Talk out your problems in a civilized fashion, or just flash your Plasma Rifle. Blast 'Em Away With V.A.T.S.! Even the odds in combat with the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System for your Pip-Boy Model 3000! V.A.T.S. allows you to pause time in combat, target specific body parts on your target, queue up attacks, and let Vault-Tec take out your aggression for you. Rain death and destruction in an all-new cinematic presentation. Mind-Blowing Artificial Intelligence! At Vault-Tec, we realize that the key to reviving civilization after a global nuclear war is people. Our best minds pooled their efforts to produce an advanced version of Radiant AI, America's First Choice in Human Interaction Simulation. Facial expressions, gestures, unique dialog, and lifelike behavior are brought together with stunning results by the latest in Vault-Tec technology. Eye-Popping Prettiness!*: Witness the harsh realities of nuclear fallout rendered like never before in modern super-deluxe HD graphics. From the barren Wasteland, to the danger-filled offices and metro tunnels of DC, to the hideous rotten flesh of a mutant's face.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												>Played New Vegas first>Didn't really enjoy it cuz of boring intro>Then get this game while On Sale>Play it  >The game has better intro than New Vegas                     >Spend most of my life in the Wasteland than in Real LifeSummary:+ Better Intro than NV, so new players can learn the Lore better+ Multi-solution, you can finish quest the way you like+ You make your own character, also what make them SPECIAL+ Unlike other RPG, you can still use weapons even if your weapon skill is low+ Karma System, one of gameplay mechanic that shouldn't removed from Fallout 4+ V.A.T.S.+ Bloody Mess perk!!            - Bugs. Yeah, every Bethesda games have bugs- 2nd most linear Fallout games- You can be evil in this game, but you can't join the Enclave (an evil corporation)- To fully enjoy the game, you need to get GOTY or at least, get the Broken Steel DLCIs it worth it? => Yes, but for some of you maybe No                               Recomended for: Those who are new to Fallout series, those who can't handle Fallout 4 but still want to play, Those who like Post-Apocalypse, First/Third Person RPG, those who want freedom on doing anythingNot Recomended for: Those who expect Turn-Based Fallout (if you do, get Wasteland instead), those who scared by mutant, ghoul, etc, for those who want Non-Linear RPGWell, Fallout 3 is a good game, just don't compare them to other Fallout games. Also, if you've finished playing this, I recommend getting Fallout: New Vegas next. Don't forget to check my New Vegas review!! xD
